<ROW>25</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``United States-Afghanistan Status of Forces Agreement Act of 2011''. Congress finds the following: Al Qaeda, a terrorist organization using Afghanistan as a base of operations, attacked the United States on September 11, 2001, killing nearly 3,000 people in New York, Pennsylvania, and Virginia. Congress passed and the President signed the Authorization for Use of Military Force (Public Law 107-40; 50 U.S.C. 1541 note) on September 18, 2001. The United States initiated Operation Enduring Freedom to combat Al Qaeda and prevent the Taliban regime in Afghanistan from providing Al Qaeda with safe harbor. The Taliban was removed from power and the United States concluded security agreements with the newly formed Afghan government. Al Qaeda no longer has a major or relevant presence in Afghanistan. The United States and Afghanistan has exchanged notes, signed agreements, and issued ``joint declarations'' on various topics, but have not entered into a bilateral agreement on the status of forces. A status of forces agreement with Afghanistan would not expressly authorize the United States to carry out military operations in Afghanistan but would recognize that such operations are ongoing. The United States is currently party to more than 100 agreements on the status of forces. A status of forces agreement may be a multilateral or bilateral agreement addressing the status of United States Armed Forces while present in a foreign country. Status of forces agreements may include--but are not limited to--how the domestic laws of the foreign jurisdiction shall be applied to United States personnel and contractors while in that country. In a similar agreement, parties have pledged to work cooperatively in a number of fields, including on diplomatic, security, economic, cultural, and law enforcement matters. In a similar agreement, a deadline has been established for the withdrawal of United States troops by a date certain. United States personnel subject to a status of forces agreement may include members of the United States Armed Forces, Department of Defense civilian employees, and contractors working for the Department of Defense. In General.--Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the President shall seek to negotiate and enter into a bilateral status of forces agreement with the Government of Afghanistan in accordance with the requirements of this section. Mandatory Elements.--The status of forces agreement specified in subsection shall, to the maximum extent practicable-- prohibit the permanent basing or military presence of United States Armed Forces in Afghanistan; provide a date, no later than 1 year after the date on which the agreement is entered into with the Government of Afghanistan, for the complete, safe, and orderly redeployment from Afghanistan of all members of the United States Armed Forces, Department of Defense civilian employees, and contractors working for the Department of Defense; and establish that the temporary presence of United States Armed Forces in Afghanistan is at the request and invitation of the sovereign Government of Afghanistan. Discretionary Elements.--The status of forces agreement specified in subsection may provide for the authorization of specific exercises, activities, or missions of the United States Armed Forces in Afghanistan. Sense of Congress.--It is the sense of Congress that the President should submit the status of forces agreement specified in subsection to the Senate for its advice and consent to ratification as a treaty or alternatively the President should request statutory authorization for the status of forces agreement by Congress. Submission to Congress.-- In general.--The President shall submit to the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives and the Select Committee on Intelligence of the Senate a copy of the status of forces agreement specified in subsection . The status of forces agreement shall be submitted in unclassified form but may contain a classified annex if necessary. Availability.--Any Senator or Member of the House of Representatives may review the copy of the status of forces agreement submitted under paragraph , including any portions of the agreement contained in the classified annex. Definition.--In paragraph , the term ``Member of the House of Representatives'' includes a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to Congress."</BILL><SUMMARY>United States-Afghanistan Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) Act of 2011 - Directs the President to authorize the use of military force against al-Qaeda and the Taliban in Afghanistan and Pakistan.Status of Forces Agreement With Afghanistan and the United States of America (USSAU) - Amends the Security Act of 1947 to provide for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan by force-neutralization and counter-terrorism forces.Requires the President to: (1) negotiate and enter into a bilateral status of forces agreement with the government of Afghanistan; (2) ensure the permanent basing or military presence of United States armed forces in Afghanistan; and (3) provide a date for the complete, safe, and orderly redeployment from Afghanistan of all members of the U.S. armed forces, Department of Defense civilian employees, and contractors working for the Department of defense.Directs the President to submit to the Senate a copy of the status of forces agreement.House of Representatives" includes a delegate or resident commissioner to congress.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.7945419549942017</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>26</ROW><BILL>"VETERANS AFFAIRS FOR VETERANS AND FAMILY MEMBERS WITH LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY. In General.-- Requirement.--Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by inserting after section 1712B the following new section: ``Sec. 1713. Mental health services; languages other than English ``Availability of Counseling in Languages Other Than English.-- In providing counseling and other mental health services authorized by law to a veteran who has limited proficiency in English, the Secretary shall ensure that such counseling and services are available to that veteran in both English and a language other than English in which the veteran is proficient, if requested by the veteran. ``Identification of Limited English Proficient Veterans.--For purposes of this section, the Secretary shall develop procedures for identifying veterans who have limited proficiency in English and of informing those veterans of the provisions of subsection .''. Clerical amendment.--The table of sections at the beginning of such chapter is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 1712B the following new item: ``1713. Mental health services; languages other than English''. Family Members.--Section 1782 of such title is amended by adding at the end the following new subsections: ``Additional Counseling.--In addition to services authorized by subsections and , the Secretary shall, in connection with the service of a veteran in the active military, naval, or air service, provide to an individual described in subsection such counseling and mental health services as are requested by the individual, except to the extent that the Secretary determines that such counseling and mental health services are not needed. ``Bilingual Counseling.--In providing counseling and mental health services under this section and bereavement counseling under section 1783 of this title, the Secretary shall ensure, in the case of an individual who has limited proficiency in English, that such counseling and services are available to that individual in both English and a language other than English in which the individual is proficient, if requested by the individual. ``For purposes of this subsection, the Secretary shall develop procedures for identifying individuals who have limited proficiency in English and of informing those individuals of the provisions of paragraph .''. Effective Date.--Section 1713 of title 38, United States Code, as added by subsection , and subsections and of section 1782 of such title, as added by subsection , shall take effect at the end of the 120-day period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act. OF EXECUTIVE ORDER 13166. System for Access to Services.--The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall implement a system by which persons with limited English proficiency can meaningfully access the services provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs consistent with, and without unduly burdening, the fundamental mission of that Department. The Secretary shall work to ensure that recipients of financial assistance under programs of the Department provide meaningful access to applicants and beneficiaries with limited English proficiency. Plan.--The Secretary shall implement a plan to improve access to programs and activities of the Department of Veterans Affairs by eligible persons with limited English proficiency. The plan shall be consistent with the standards set forth in the guidance issued by the Attorney General and shall include the steps the Secretary will take to ensure that eligible persons with limited English proficiency can meaningfully access the programs and activities of the Department. In developing and implementing the plan under section 2, the Secretary shall, at a minimum, carry out the following: The Secretary shall conduct a thorough assessment of the language needs of the population served by the Department of Veterans Affairs, including identifying the non-English languages that are likely to be encountered. The Secretary shall develop and implement a comprehensive language assistance program, which shall include-- hiring bilingual staff and interpreters for patient and client contact positions; and translating written materials (such as consent forms, notice of free language assistance, and outreach materials) into languages other than English. The Secretary shall train staff of the Department on the access policy of the Department with respect to persons with limited English proficiency and on carrying out that policy. The Secretary shall establish vigilant monitoring and oversight to ensure that persons with limited English proficiency have meaningful access to health care and services. The Secretary shall establish a task force to evaluate implementation and to prioritize needed actions to implement the access plan for persons with limited English proficiency. The Secretary shall develop a specific plan to ensure seamless transition of veterans and their families from benefits and services provided by the Department of Defense to benefits and services provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs, including bilingual readjustment and bereavement counseling. The Secretary shall establish a process to translate vital documents and other materials, including materials on the World Wide Web, brochures distributed as part of outreach efforts to servicemembers transitioning into civilian life, and the post-deployment health reassessment program. The Secretary shall conduct outreach to veterans and their families in communities which may have higher proportions of populations with limited English proficiency to ensure they are aware of eligibility for benefits and services from the Department of Veterans Affairs. DIRECTIVE ON IMPROVING ACCESS TO SERVICES FOR PERSONS WITH LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY. Report Required.--Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall submit to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and House of Representatives a report on the implementation by the Veterans Health Administration of the Department of Veterans Affairs of the directive of the Veterans Health Administration designated ``VHA Directive 2002- 006'' that was issued by the Under Secretary for Health of the Department of Veterans Affairs on January 31, 2002, and that issued policy to implement prohibitions on discrimination on the basis of national origin for persons with limited English proficiency in Federally-conducted programs and activities and in Federal financial assisted programs. Capacity to Provide Services to LEP Servicemembers.--The Secretary shall include in the report an analysis of the capacity of the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide services to members of the Armed Forces with limited English proficiency."</BILL><SUMMARY>Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to develop procedures for:  (1) availability of counseling and other mental health services in languages other than english; and (2) identification of limited english proficient veterans.Veterans Affairs Act of 2003 - Amends the VA Act to: (1) require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in connection with the service of a veteran in the active military, naval, or air service, to provide counseling and mental health services in both english and English, except to the extent that the Secretary determines that such counseling and services are not needed.Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to develop and implement a plan to improve access to services provided by the Department of Veterans affairs by persons with limited english proficiency. <ROW>27</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Ensuring Defense Support to Catastrophic Incident Response Act of 2008''. Congress makes the following findings: The United States faces real threats of man-made and natural disasters which could result in catastrophic consequences to the Nation, its resources, and its people. Because of the scale of the potential consequences of these threats, they may constitute threats to national security and will require the full range of Federal resources to save lives, minimize human suffering, protect property, and mitigate damage. Because of its manpower, communications, logistics, and other capabilities, the Department of Defense is uniquely suited to provide critical support to other departments and agencies of the Federal Government, State and local governments, and governments of the Commonwealths and possessions of the United States in response to a catastrophic incident in the United States. Planning and preparation for and execution of civil support operations in responding to catastrophic incidents in support of the Department of Homeland Security and State and local governments is a national security issue. A successful response to catastrophic incidents in the United States requires coordinated strategic plans and detailed operational plans with specific tasking and sourcing. The Department of Defense must develop such plans and should maintain the required units and assets at the appropriate level of readiness in order to deliver the capabilities which will be required in a response led by the Department of Homeland Security. The National Guard and Reserves are forward-deployed in communities throughout the United States, are integrated with State and local governments, and have considerable homeland- related capabilities. The Department of Defense and the United States Northern Command must therefore consider the plans and capabilities of the National Guard and Reserves, and State and local governments, in plans for civil support operations. IN RESPONSE TO CATASTROPHIC INCIDENTS IN THE UNITED STATES. Support Authorized.--Part I of subtitle A of title 10, United States Code, is amended by inserting after chapter 18 the following new chapter: ``CHAPTER 19--SUPPORT OF DOMESTIC CIVILIAN AUTHORITIES IN RESPONSE TO CATASTROPHIC INCIDENTS IN THE UNITED STATES ``Sec. ``390. Department of Defense support of domestic civilian authorities in response to catastrophic incidents in the United States. ``Sec. 390. Department of Defense support of domestic civilian authorities in response to catastrophic incidents in the United States ``In General.--Subject to the authority, direction, and control of the President, the Department of Defense shall undertake civil support operations in response to catastrophic incidents in the United States. ``Plans for Support.--For purposes of carrying out the requirement in subsection , the Secretary of Defense shall, in conjunction with the Secretary of Homeland Security, develop comprehensive plans for civil support operations. ``The plans required under this subsection shall include strategies for the use of the armed forces, including units and personnel of the regular components of the armed forces, units and personnel of the National Guard (including personnel on active duty under this title, in status under title 32, and in State status, consistent with section 1814of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 (10 U.S.C. 113 note)), units and personnel of the other reserve components of the armed forces, the civilian personnel of the Department of Defense, and, if the Secretary considers it appropriate for purposes of the plans, contractors of the Department of Defense. ``The plans required under this subsection shall be developed in coordination with other departments and agencies of the Federal Government with homeland security responsibilities as part of an established national planning process and shall include the development of operations plans required by section 653of the Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act of 2006 (6 U.S.C. 753). ``The plans required under this subsection shall be developed to execute strategic requirements established by the Secretary of Homeland Security though an established national planning process. ``Implementation and Execution of Plans.--In implementing the plans developed under subsection , the Secretary of Defense shall-- ``ensure that-- ``the Department of Defense is organized and equipped with the capabilities and resources required to execute the plans; and ``the capabilities and resources referred to in subparagraph are available, accessible, and maintained at the appropriate readiness status to enable deployment in accordance with the plans; and ``ensure that any capabilities and resources identified under paragraph , when appropriate, train and participate in exercises, including-- ``exercises administered under the national exercise program carried out under section 648of the Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act of 2006 (6 U.S.C. 748); and ``other exercises determined appropriate by the Secretary of Defense to ensure such capabilities and resources are maintained at the appropriate state of readiness. ``Budget.--The budget of the Department of Defense for any fiscal year (as submitted to Congress pursuant to section 1105 of title 31) shall include a request for funds sufficient to carry out the requirements of this section in such fiscal year. The request for a fiscal year under this subsection shall set forth separately the following: ``Each component, program, or activity of the Department of Defense that will carry out the requirements of this section in such fiscal year. ``The amount requested for each such component, program, or activity to carry out such requirements in such fiscal year. ``Construction.--Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting or limiting the authority of the Department of Defense to provide support operations in response to a disaster or incident that is not a catastrophic incident as otherwise provided by law. ``Reports.--Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this section, and every two years thereafter, the Secretary of Defense shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the implementation of the requirements of this section, including a discussion of the development and implementation of the plans required by subsection . ``Each report under this subsection shall be submitted in unclassified form, but may include a classified annex. ``Definitions.--In this section: ``The term `catastrophic incident' has the meaning given that term in section 501of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 (6 U.S.C. 311). ``The term `civil support operation' means a mission performed by the Department of Defense in support of other departments or agencies of the Federal Government, State or local governments, or governments of the Commonwealths or possessions of the United States in their efforts to prevent, protect against, prepare for, respond to, and recover from natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other man-made disasters.''. Clerical Amendments.--The tables of chapters at the beginning of title, United States Code, and at the beginning of part I of subtitle A of such title, are each amended by inserting after the item relating to chapter 18 the following new item: ``19. Support of Domestic Civilian Authorities in Response 390.''. to Catastrophic Incidents in the United States. Section 118 of title 10, United States Code, is amended-- by transferring subsection , as added by section 942of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 (Public Law 110-181; 122 Stat. 288), to the end of such section 118 and redesignating such subsection, as so transferred, as subsection ; and by inserting after subsection , as added by section 951of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 (122 Stat. 290), the following new subsection: ``Consideration of Department of Defense Roles and Responsibilities in Responding to Catastrophic Incidents.--The first national security strategy and national defense strategy prepared after the date of the enactment of this subsection shall include guidance for military planners-- ``to determine the appropriate roles and responsibilities of the Department of Defense, in coordination with and in support of the Department of Homeland Security and other departments and agencies of the Federal Government with homeland security responsibilities and with State, local, and tribal governments, in responding to catastrophic incidents; ``to update defense plans based on such determinations, including working with the Department of Homeland Security and other departments and agencies of the Federal Government with homeland security responsibilities in responding to such incidents; and ``to develop the capabilities needed to execute such plans. ``The first quadrennial defense review prepared after the date of the enactment of this subsection shall examine the capabilities of the armed forces to support civil authorities in responding to catastrophic incidents. ``In this subsection: ``The term `catastrophic incident' has the meaning given that term in section 501of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 (6 U.S.C. 311). ``The term `national security strategy' means the annual national security strategy report of the President under section 108 of the National Security Act of 1947 (50 U.S.C. 404a).''. Nothing in this Act or the amendments made by this Act may be construed-- to modify the restrictions on the role of the Department of Defense in law enforcement operations within the United States; to affect the authority of the Governor of a State to respond to a natural disaster, act of terrorism, or other man- made disaster within the United States; or to affect the authority of the Governor of a State to exercise command and control over the National Guard of that State while in State status or in title 32, United States Code, status. In this Act: The term ``catastrophic incident'' has the meaning given that term in section 501of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 (6 U.S.C. 311). The term ``civil support operation'' means a mission performed by the Department of Defense in support of other departments or agencies of the Federal Government, State or local governments, or governments of the Commonwealths or possessions of the United States in their efforts to prevent, protect against, prepare for, respond to, and recover from natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other man-made disasters. There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as are necessary to carry out this Act and the amendments made by this Act."</BILL><SUMMARY>Ensuring Defense Support to Credible Exactives Act of 2008 - Directs the Department of Defense (DOD) to provide critical support to other Federal departments and agencies in response to a catastrophic incident in the United States.Directs the Department of Defense and the United States Northern Command to develop plans for civil support operations.Directs the Secretary to develop comprehensive plans for civil support operations in response to disasters in the United States.Directs the Secretary to ensure that: (1) the Department of Defense is organized and equipped with the capabilities and resources required to execute the plans; and (2) that any capabilities and resource identified under the National Exercise Program, when appropriate, train and participate in exercises administered under the national exercise program.Directs the Secretary to report to Congress on each component, program, or activity of the Department of Defense that will carry out such requirements in such fiscal year.Civil Support Operations Act of 2002 - Amends the Defense Department's (DOJ) Defense Authorization Act to extend the authority of the Secretary of Defense (DOOD) to: (1) support of domestic civilian authorities in their efforts to prevent, prepare for, respond to, and recover from natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other man-made disasters; Amends the Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) Act to: (1) modify the restrictions on the role of the Department (DOD) in law enforcement operations within the United Nations; (2) affect the governor's authority to exercise command and control over the national guard of that state while in state status or in title 32, United States code, status; and (3) make such mission an authorized one.Protect against, prepare for, respond to, and recover from natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other man-made disasters.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.5048941373825073</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>28</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Energy Security Act of 2011''. In this Act: Administrator.--The term ``Administrator'' means the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Council.--The term ``Council'' means the National Energy Security Council established by section 4. National energy security program.--The term ``national energy security program'' means the national energy security program established by section 3. National oil independence goal.--The term ``national oil independence goal'' means the national oil independence goal established under section 3. National oil independence plan.--The term ``national oil independence plan'' means the national oil independence plan established under section 3. Establishment.--There is established in the Executive Office of the President the national energy security program. Mission.--The mission of the national energy security program shall be to coordinate the activities and policies of the Federal Government to ensure, to the maximum extent practicable, that the United States meets-- goals for reducing oil dependence, oil imports, and oil consumption; and other energy policy goals, including goals for-- enhancing the competitiveness of the United States in clean energy technology; strengthening clean energy technology manufacturing in the United States; reducing greenhouse gas emissions; and reducing hazardous pollutants. National Oil Independence Goal.-- In general.--Subject to paragraph , it is the goal of the United States to reduce oil consumption by the quantity that is equal to or greater than the quantity of oil imported by the United States from outside of North America by calendar year 2030 (as compared to the rate of oil consumption projected for calendar year 2030 as of the date of enactment of this Act). Adjustments.--The President, in consultation with the Council-- may adjust the numeric goal for calendar year 2030 established under paragraph ; shall ensure that any new goal established under subparagraph represents the maximum practicable oil savings achievable, taking into account other benefits of reducing oil consumption (including economic, security, and environmental benefits) and costs or other economic effects; and if any new goal established under subparagraph is lower than the goal established under paragraph , shall establish an additional goal for reducing oil consumption in the United Sates by a quantity that is equal to or greater than the quantity of oil imported by the United States from outside of North America on the fastest timeline practicable, taking into account other benefits of reducing oil consumption (including economic, security, and environmental benefits) and costs or other economic effects. National Oil Independence Plan.-- In general.--The President, in coordination with the Council and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, shall-- develop a national oil independence plan that describes programs and activities that will be implemented to meet or exceed the national oil independence goal and other goals established pursuant to subsection ; submit the national oil independence plan to Congress not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act; and submit an updated national oil independence plan to Congress every 2 years thereafter. Review of federal policies, programs, and authorities.--Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the President, in coordination with the Council and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, shall review existing programs and authorities of the Federal Government and other applicable policies (including tax policies) to determine-- which programs, authorities, or policies could be used to accelerate reductions in oil dependence; and any means by which the programs, authorities, or policies-- could be used to maximize reductions in oil dependence; or would require modification in order to be used to maximize reductions in oil dependence; and which programs, authorities, or policies have the effect of increasing oil consumption and oil dependence or otherwise create barriers to reducing oil consumption and oil dependence; and the manner by which the programs, authorities, or policies-- have the effect of encouraging oil consumption or oil dependence or otherwise create barriers to reducing oil consumption and oil dependence; and could be modified or eliminated to help meet the goal of reducing oil consumption and oil dependence. Contents.--At a minimum, the national oil independence plan shall-- describe the results and conclusions of the review conducted under paragraph ; as appropriate, include-- the use of programs, authorities, or policies described in paragraph ; and if existing authority allows, proposals to modify or eliminate programs, authorities, or policies described in paragraph ; include recommendations to Congress for legislation that would further-- promote reductions in oil consumption and oil dependence; reduce barriers to reducing oil consumption and oil dependence; and help meet the energy policy goals of the United States; include a timetable for achieving the national oil independence goal, including interim targets on not less than a biennial basis; a plan for coordinating actions across the Federal Government to ensure, to the maximum extent practicable, that the national oil independence goal is met; and a timeline for issuing rules, Executive orders, or other policy instruments that will implement the recommendations contained the national oil independence plan. Annual Requests to Congress.--When submitting annual budget requests to Congress, the President shall include-- requests for sufficient funding for such programs the President considers appropriate to implement the national oil independence plan; and if the amount of funding is not sufficient to meet the national oil independence goal, a description of the amount of funding that would be necessary to meet the goal; requests for such additional authorities or changes to existing laws or authorities as the President considers appropriate in order to implement the national oil independence plan; and if the amount of funding is not sufficient to meet the national oil independence goal, a description of such additional authority or changes to existing laws or authorities as would be necessary to meet the goal; and a report on the oil consumption and imports of the United States relative to the national oil independence goal and the interim targets and timelines established in the national oil independence plan. Establishment.--There is established in the Executive Office of the President a National Energy Security Council. Mission.--The mission of the Council shall be to assist and advise the President in-- establishing the national oil independence goal in numeric terms of barrels per day of oil consumption, based on the most recent consumption estimates by the Energy Information Administration; meeting the national oil independence goal; developing the national oil independence plan and the requests described in section 3; coordinating the policies, programs, and activities of the national energy security program in order to implement the national oil independence plan and meet the national oil independence goal; and ensuring that policy decisions and programs are consistent with the energy policy goals of the United States. Membership.--The membership of the Council shall consist of-- the Secretary of Energy; the Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs; the Secretary of Transportation; the Administrator; the Secretary of the Treasury; the Director of the National Economic Council; the Secretary of Agriculture; the Chair of the Council on Environmental Quality; the Secretary of State; and the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. Chair.--The President shall act as Chair of the Council. Authorization of Appropriations.--There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section such sums as are necessary."</BILL><SUMMARY>Energy Security Act of 2011 - Directs the President to establish in the Executive Office the National Energy Security Program.National Oil Independence Goal - Amends the Energy Policy Act of the United States to reduce oil consumption by a quantity equal to or greater than the quantity of oil imported by the United states from outside of North America by calendar year 2030 (as compared to the rate of oil consumption projected for this date).Directs the President to develop a national oil independence plan that describes programs and activities that will be implemented to meet or exceed the National Oil Independence goal and to determine: (1) which programs, authorities, or policies could be used to accelerate reductions in oil dependence; and (2) review of federal policies, programs, and authorities to determine which programs and authorities are best suited to accelerate the reduction in dependence.Requires the National Oil Independence Plan to describe the results of the review and recommendations to Congress regarding:   the use of programs, authorities, or policies to reduce oil dependence;  the methods by which such programs or policies have the effect of encouraging oil consumption or oil dependence or otherwise create barriers to reducing oil consumption and oil dependence, and  the manner by which they may be modified or eliminated to meet the goal of reducing oil dependence.Directs the President to submit annual budget requests to Congress.Directs the Council to assist and advise the President in: (1) establishing the National Oil Independence Goal in numeric terms and in terms of barrels per day of oil consumption; (2) meeting the goal; (3) coordinating the policies, programs, and activities of the National Energy Security Agency (NESSA) in order to implement the national oil independence plan; and (4) ensuring that policy decisions and programs are consistent with the energy policy goals of the United States.Directs the Secretary of Energy to act as chair of the Council.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.27162498235702515</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>29</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Return of Talent Act''. In General.--Title III of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1401 et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 317 the following: ``temporary absence of persons participating in the return of talent program ``Sec. 317A. In General.--The Secretary of Homeland Security shall establish the Return of Talent Program to permit eligible aliens to temporarily return to the alien's country of citizenship in order to make a material contribution to that country if the country is engaged in post-conflict reconstruction activities, for a period not exceeding 24 months, unless an exception is granted under subsection . ``Eligible Alien.--An alien is eligible to participate in the Return of Talent Program established under subsection if the alien meets the special immigrant description under section 101. ``Family Members.--The spouse, parents, siblings, and any children of an alien who participates in the Return of Talent Program established under subsection may return to such alien's country of citizenship with the alien and reenter the United States with the alien. ``Extension of Time.--The Secretary of Homeland Security may extend the 24-month period referred to in subsection upon a showing that circumstances warrant that an extension is necessary for post- conflict reconstruction efforts. ``Residency Requirements.--An immigrant described in section 101who participates in the Return of Talent Program established under subsection , and the spouse, parents, siblings, and any children who accompany such immigrant to that immigrant's country of citizenship, shall be considered, during such period of participation in the program-- ``for purposes of section 316, physically present and residing in the United States for purposes of naturalization within the meaning of that section; and ``for purposes of section 316, to meet the continuous residency requirements in that section. ``Oversight and Enforcement.--The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall oversee and enforce the requirements of this section.''. Table of Contents.--The table of contents for the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101 et seq.) is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 317 the following: ``317A. Temporary absence of persons participating in the Return of Talent Program.''. Section 101of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101) is amended-- in subparagraph , by inserting a semicolon after ``Improvement Act of 1998''; in subparagraph , by striking the period and inserting ``; or''; and by adding at the end the following: ``an immigrant who-- ``has been lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence; ``demonstrates an ability and willingness to make a material contribution to the post-conflict reconstruction in the alien's country of citizenship; and ``as determined by the Secretary of State in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security-- ``is a citizen of a country in which Armed Forces of the United States are engaged, or have engaged in the 10 years preceding such determination, in combat or peacekeeping operations; or ``is a citizen of a country where authorization for United Nations peacekeeping operations was initiated by the United Nations Security Council during the 10 years preceding such determination.''. Not later than 24 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Homeland Security shall submit a report to Congress that describes-- the countries of citizenship of the participants in the Return of Talent Program established under section 2; the post-conflict reconstruction efforts that benefited, or were made possible, through participation in the program; and any other information that the Secretary of Homeland Security determines to be appropriate. Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Homeland Security shall promulgate regulations to carry out this Act. There is authorized to be appropriated to the Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services for each of the fiscal years 2004 and 2005, such sums as may be necessary to carry out this Act."</BILL><SUMMARY>Return of Talent Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to establish the return of talent program to permit eligible aliens to temporarily return to the alien's country of citizenship in order to make a material contribution to that country if the country is engaged in post-conflict reconstruction activities.Directs the Department of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, to oversee and enforce the requirements of this Act.Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to: (1) extend the period through which the Department of State determines eligibility for permanent residence for aliens who have been lawfully admitted to the United States for a year or more and demonstrate an ability and willingness to make a material contribution to the post-conflict reconstruction in the alien's country of citizenship; and (2) make such determination as determined by the Secretary of State in consultation with Homeland Security.Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to promulgate regulations to carry out this Act.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.9825945496559143</ALIGNSCORE>

available entitlement under this chapter.''. Effective Dates.--The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. Notwithstanding the effective date under paragraph of the amendment to section 3564 of title 38, United States Code, made by subsection , the Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall make the first increase in the aggregate amount of educational assistance under section 3532 of such title as required by such section 3564 (as so amended) for fiscal year 2006."</BILL><SUMMARY>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) expand and enhance educational assistance for survivors and dependents of veterans; (2) restatement of continuing requirements for the payment of educational assistance; and (3) repeal of such prohibition if an individual has to discontinue a course or courses if the Secretary finds that the individual has failed to receive credit or training time toward completion of his approved educational, professional, or vocational objective.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) require the Secretary of Education, at the request of an eligible person, to determine whether such person is in need of special restorative training or to prescribe a course which is suitable to accomplish the purposes of this bill.Amends the Act to authorize educational assistance to be paid for by the Secretary of Agriculture for: (1) institutional courses and alternate phases of training in a business or industrial establishment;
