<ROW>39</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Renewable Energy Act for Credit on Taxes''. In General.--Subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to refundable credits) is amended by redesignating section 35 as section 36 and by inserting after section 34 the following new section: `` ``Allowance of Credit.--In the case of an individual, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax imposed by this chapter for the taxable year an amount equal to 35 percent of the expenditures for renewable energy property made by the taxpayer during the taxable year. ``Limitation.-- ``Maximum credit.--The credit allowed under subsection shall not exceed the lesser of-- ``$6,000 ($50,000 in the case of renewable energy property used for nonresidential business purposes) for each system of renewable energy property, or ``$4.50 per watt of rated system electricity output or equivalent. ``Location of structure.--No expenditure may be taken into account under this section unless such expenditure is made by the taxpayer for property installed on or in connection with a structure which is located in the United States. ``Rating system electricity output.--For purposes of paragraph , the rated system electricity output or equivalent for-- ``solar water heating property shall be the output determined by the Secretary on the basis of evidence acceptable to the Secretary which is submitted by manufacturers of such property and which includes information relating to one year of reliable operation of such property, ``photovoltaic property shall be the output certified by a nationally recognized testing laboratory as meeting the requirements of the Underwriters Laboratory Standard 1703, ``wind energy property shall be the output-- ``certified as meeting the requirements of a small wind turbine-specific safety or performance standard adopted by a national or international standards setting body, including International Electric Code 61400-2, or ``determined by the Secretary on the basis of evidence acceptable to the Secretary which is submitted by manufacturers of such property and which includes information relating to one year of reliable operation of such property at a site with average annual wind speeds of at least 12 miles per hour, and ``fuel cell property shall be the output certified as meeting the requirements specified by the American Gas Association in document entitled `AGA Requirements for Fuel Cell Power Plants', No. 8-90. The Secretary shall determine who makes the certifications for purposes of subparagraphs and . ``Definitions.--For purposes of this section-- ``Renewable energy property.--The term `renewable energy property' means property which is-- ``qualified solar water heating property, ``qualified photovoltaic property, ``qualified wind energy property, or ``qualified fuel cell property. ``Qualified solar water heating property.--The term `qualified solar water heating property' means property that uses solar energy to heat water for use in a structure with respect to which a majority of the energy is derived from the sun. ``Qualified photovoltaic property.--The term `qualified photovoltaic property' means property that uses solar energy to generate electricity for use in a structure. ``Solar panels.--No expenditure relating to a solar panel or other property installed as a roof (or portion thereof) shall fail to be treated as property described in paragraph or solely because it constitutes a structural component of the structure on which it is installed. ``Qualified wind energy property.--The term `qualified wind energy property' means property which uses wind energy to generate electricity for use in a structure. ``Qualified fuel cell property.--The term `qualified fuel cell property' means property which uses an electrochemical process to generate electricity for use in a structure. ``Labor costs.--Expenditures for labor costs properly allocable to the onsite preparation, assembly, or original installation of the property described in paragraph , , , or and for piping or wiring to interconnect such property to the dwelling unit shall be taken into account for purposes of this section. ``Special Rules.--For purposes of this section-- ``Dollar amounts in case of joint occupancy.--In the case of any structure which is jointly occupied and used during any calendar year by 2 or more persons the following shall apply: ``The amount of the credit allowable under subsection by reason of expenditures (as the case may be) made during such calendar year by any of such persons with respect to such structure shall be determined by treating all of such persons as 1 taxpayer whose taxable year is such calendar year. ``There shall be allowable with respect to such expenditures to each of such person, a credit under subsection for the taxable year in which such calendar year ends in an amount which bears the same ratio to the amount determined under subparagraph as the amount of such expenditures made by such person during such calendar year bears to the aggregate of such expenditures made by all of such persons during such calendar year. ``Tenant-stockholder in cooperative housing corporation.--In the case of an individual who is a tenant- stockholder (as defined in section 216) in a cooperative housing corporation (as defined in such section), such individual shall be treated as having made his tenant- stockholder's proportionate share (as defined in section 216) of any expenditures of such corporation. ``Condominiums.-- ``In general.--In the case of an individual who is a member of a condominium management association with respect to a condominium which he owns, such individual shall be treated as having made his proportionate share of any expenditures of such association. ``Condominium management association.--For purposes of this paragraph, the term `condominium management association' means an organization which meets the requirements of paragraph of section 528(other than subparagraph thereof) with respect to a condominium project substantially all of the units of which are used as residences. ``Joint ownership of items of renewable energy property.-- ``In general.--Any expenditure otherwise qualifying as an expenditure described in paragraph , , , or of subsection shall not be treated as failing to so qualify merely because such expenditure was made with respect to 2 or more structures. ``Limits applied separately.--In the case of any expenditure described in subparagraph , the amount of the credit allowable under subsection shall (subject to paragraph ) be computed separately with respect to the amount of the expenditure made for each structure. ``Allocation in certain cases.--If 80 percent or more of the use of an item is for residential purposes, then the item shall be treated as used only for residential purposes. ``When expenditure made; amount of expenditure.-- ``In general.--Except as provided in subparagraph , an expenditure with respect to an item shall be treated as made when the original installation of the item is completed. ``Expenditures part of building construction.-- In the case of an expenditure in connection with the construction or reconstruction of a structure, such expenditure shall be treated as made when the original use of the constructed or reconstructed structure by the taxpayer begins. ``Amount.--The amount of any expenditure shall be the cost thereof. ``Reduction of credit for grants, tax-exempt bonds, and subsidized energy financing.--The rules of section 29shall apply for purposes of this section. ``Denial of double benefit.--No credit shall be allowed under subsection for any expense for which a deduction or credit is allowed under any other provision of this chapter. ``Basis Adjustments.--For purposes of this subtitle, if a credit is allowed under this section for any expenditure with respect to any property, the increase in the basis of such property which would (but for this subsection) result from such expenditure shall be reduced by the amount of the credit so allowed. ``Termination.--The credit allowed under this section shall not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006.''. Conforming and Technical Amendments.-- Subsection of section 1016 of such Code is amended by striking ``and'' at the end of paragraph , by striking the period at the end of paragraph and inserting ``; and'', and by adding at the end the following new paragraph: ``to the extent provided in section 35, in the case of amounts with respect to which a credit has been allowed under section 35.'' Paragraph of section 1324of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting ``or from section 35 of such Code'' before the period at the end. The table of sections for such subpart C is amended by striking the item relating to section 35 and inserting the following new items: ``Sec. 35. Renewable energy property. ``Sec. 36. Overpayment of taxes.'' Effective Date.--The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2001."</BILL><SUMMARY>Renewable Energy Act of 2018 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for renewable energy property expense incurred by taxpayers during the taxable year.Directs the Secretary to determine who makes the certifications on the basis of evidence acceptable to the Secretary which includes information relating to one year of reliable operation of such property at a site with average annual wind speeds of at least 12 miles per hour, and whether the property meets such requirements.Sets forth provisions regarding renewable energy property. <ROW>40</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Census Improvement Act''. PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM FOR THE 2010 CENSUS. In General.--Participation in the Planning Partnership Program for the 2010 census of population shall not be allowed in the case of-- an organization which has been indicted for a violation under Federal or State law relating to an election for Federal or State office; or an organization which employs applicable individuals. Applicable Individual Defined.--For purposes of this section, the term ``applicable individual'' means an individual who-- is-- employed by the organization in a permanent or temporary capacity; contracted or retained by the organization; or acting on behalf of, or with the express or apparent authority of, the organization; and has been indicted for a violation under Federal or State law relating to an election for Federal or State office. State Defined.--For purposes of this section, the term ``State'' includes the District of Columbia. PROVISIONS RELATING TO CONFIDENTIALITY OF CERTAIN INFORMATION. Rulemaking Power.--The succeeding provisions of this section are enacted by Congress-- as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate and the House of Representatives, respectively, and as such shall be deemed a part of the rules of each House, respectively, and shall supersede other rules only to the extent that they are inconsistent with such other rules; and with the full recognition of the constitutional right of either House to change the rules (so far as relating to the procedures of that House) at any time, in the same manner, and to the same extent as any other rule of that House. Voting Requirement.--No bill or joint resolution, amendment, or conference report containing a provision which would have the effect of repealing, suspending, or otherwise limiting the application of section 9 of title 13, United States Code (relating to information as confidential; exception) shall be considered as passed or agreed to, by either House of Congress, unless so passed or agreed to by a vote of not less than two-thirds of the Members of such House voting. In General.--Not later than 6 months after the deadline for the submission described in subsection , the Government Accountability Office shall review and report to Congress on the questions proposed to be included in the 2010 census of population and the American Community Survey (next scheduled to be carried out after the end of the 6-month period beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act). Requirements.--In carrying out this section, the Government Accountability Office shall specifically address-- the reasons for each question proposed to be included in the survey or census and the purposes for which the information obtained from respondents is likely to be used; alternative means by which the same information could be obtained other than by inclusion in such census or survey, as the case may be; and the relative advantages and disadvantages of obtaining the information through a census or survey (as the case may be) as compared to the alternative means referred to in paragraph . Submission of Questions.--Not later than 30 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Commerce shall submit to the Government Accountability Office-- a copy of each question proposed to be included in the upcoming American Community Survey (as described in subsection ) and the 2010 census of population; and with respect to each question under paragraph , the views of the Secretary of Commerce (or designee) with respect to paragraphs through of subsection . NON-HOUSEHOLD MEMBERS NO LONGER ALLOWED. In General.--Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no officer, employee, or other person referred to in subchapter II of chapter 1 of title 13, United States Code, may, in the conduct of the American Community Survey or the 2010 census of population, seek answers to any questions relating to any household or any member of such household from any person who is not a member of such household. Implementation.--The Secretary of Commerce shall take such measures as may be necessary to provide for the implementation of subsection . For purposes of this Act-- the term ``census of population'' has the meaning given such term by section 141of title 13, United States Code; and the term ``Member'' means a Member of Congress, as defined by section 2106 of title 5, United States Code."</BILL><SUMMARY>Census Improvement Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit the use of federal funds for the purpose of the exchange of information and information among organizations under the Bureau of Management and Budget (MBI) for purposes of the 2010 census. <ROW>41</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Electronic Campaign Disclosure Act of 1998''. ELECTION COMMISSION REPORTS; ACCESS THROUGH INTERNET SITE. Electronic Filing Through the Internet.--Section 304of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (2 U.S.C. 434) is amended to read as follows: ``Through a competitive bidding process, the Commission shall establish a public Internet site not later than January 1, 1999, with the following features: ``Any person filing a report required by this Act may post the report directly on the site. ``Any member of the public may obtain the reports posted on the site (together with any other information the Commission may make available through the site) at any time. ``Any information in a report posted on the site shall be subject to the same prohibition on sale and use as information from a report or statement under paragraph . ``All information posted on the site shall be integrated in a manner which permits users to search the information across categories and sources. ``The Commission shall permit each person required to file a report under this Act to file the report by posting it directly on the Internet site established under subparagraph , or by filing it by such electronic method as the Commission may designate to enable the Commission to post the report on such site immediately upon receipt. ``The Commission shall require a person to file a report under this Act in accordance with the methods described in clause during an election cycle if the aggregate amount of contributions or expenditures reported previously by the person during the cycle exceeds $25,000. ``The Commission shall provide for one or more methods (other than requiring a signature on the report being filed) for verification of reports filed in accordance with the methods described in subparagraph . Any verification under the preceding sentence shall be treated for all purposes (including penalties for perjury) in the same manner as a verification by signature. ``As used in this paragraph, the term ``report'' means, with respect to the Commission, a report, designation, or statement required by this Act to be filed with the Commission.''. Requiring Commission To Make Software Available.--Section 311of such Act (2 U.S.C. 438) is amended-- by striking ``and'' at the end of paragraph ; by striking the period at the end of paragraph and inserting ``; and''; and by adding at the end the following new paragraph: ``through competitive bidding, obtain and provide for computer software required to carry out section 304.''. Internet Defined.--Section 301 of such Act (2 U.S.C. 431) is amended by striking paragraph and inserting the following new paragraph: ``The term `Internet' means the international computer network of both Federal and non-Federal interoperable packet-switched data networks.''. 10 DAYS OF RECEIPT. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (2 U.S.C. 434) is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection: ``If a political committee is required under subsection to file reports under this Act electronically during an election cycle, the committee shall file a report with the Commission listing each contribution of $100 or more received by the committee during the cycle after the date on which such subsection first applies to the committee. The committee shall file such report not later than 10 days after receipt, and shall include the identification of the contributor, the date of receipt and amount of the contribution, and (in the case of an authorized committee of a candidate) the name of the candidate and the office sought by the candidate. ``The report required under this paragraph shall be in addition to all other reports required under this Act.''. COMMITTEES SUBJECT TO EXPEDITED REPORTING; SHORTENING DEADLINE FOR REPORTING TO WITHIN 24 HOURS OF RECEIPT. Section 304of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (2 U.S.C. 434) is amended-- by redesignating subparagraph as subparagraph ; and by inserting after subparagraph the following new subparagraph: ``In the case of a principal campaign committee which is required under subsection to file reports under this Act electronically during an election cycle, subparagraph shall apply with respect to any contribution received by the committee after the date on which such subsection first applies to the committee as if-- ``the reference to `$1,000' were a reference to `$100'; ``the reference to `20th day' were a reference to `90th day'; and ``the reference in the second sentence to `48 hours' were a reference to `24 hours'.''. Section 301 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (2 U.S.C. 431) is amended by striking paragraph and inserting the following new paragraph: ``The term `election cycle' means-- ``in the case of a candidate or the authorized committees of a candidate, the term beginning on the day after the date of the most recent general election for the specific office or seat which such candidate seeks and ending on the date of the next general election for such office or seat; or ``for all other persons, the term beginning on the first day following the date of the last general election and ending on the date of the next general election.''. The amendments made by this Act shall apply with respect to elections occurring after January 1999."</BILL><SUMMARY>Electronic Campaign Disclosure Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to: (1) require electronic preservation and filing of Federal election commission reports; (2) any member of the public may obtain the reports posted on the site together with any other information the commission may make available through the site; and (3) prohibit the sale and use of any information in a report or statement subject to the same prohibition on sale, use, and use as information from a report that is otherwise made public.Requires each person required to file a report under this Act to: (1) submit a report to the Commission in accordance with the methods described above; and (2) require each such person to submit an electronic report by posting it directly on the Internet site established by the Commission; and, (3) submit such report by filing it by any electronic method as the commission may designate to enable the commission to post the report on such site immediately upon receipt.Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 - Amends the Federal Elections Campaign Act to: (1) require Federal Election Commission (FEC) to report to Congress on all contributions made to and received through competitive bidding, obtain and provide for computer software required to carry out Federal election campaign (EDC) requirements; and (2) require the Federal Interoperable packet-switched Internet (FIT) to be made available to the public.Requires: (1) a principal campaign committee which is required to file such reports electronically during an election cycle to include the names of contributors and campaign officials; and (2) a list of authorized committees seeking to elect a candidate. <ROW>42</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Pharmaceutical Products Price Equity Act''. The Congress finds the following: Modern life enhancing and life sustaining drugs are the products of decades of scientific research and practice. The refining and production of products by American pharmaceutical enterprises must be appropriately compensated. The pricing of American pharmaceutical products varies greatly from country to country with the corporate owners of such products voluntarily assuming no losses by always selling their products above the cost of production. Considering the vital life and death nature of pharmaceutical products, it is appropriate that the United States Government, in harmony with other nations belonging to the World Trade Organization, should engage in the reasonable regulation of the prices of pharmaceutical products. Presidential Authority.--The President shall issue such orders and regulations, and establish such procedures and reporting requirements, as the President determines to be appropriate to ensure that no pharmaceutical product (as defined by the President in such regulation or order) is sold to any consumer in the United States at a price that is more than 6 percent above the average retail price at which such pharmaceutical product is sold in the 5 most industrialized, free-market countries, other than the United States, as determined by the President. Delegation.--The President may delegate the performance of any function under this section to any officer of any Federal department or agency who has been appointed by the President, by and with the consent of the Senate. Confidentiality of Information.--All information reported to or otherwise obtained by any person exercising any authority under this section which contains or relates to a trade secret or other matter referred to in section 1905 of title 18, United States Code, shall be considered confidential for purposes of that section, except that such information may be disclosed to any other officer or employee of the United States involved in carrying out this section solely for the purpose of carrying out, and enforcing compliance with, this section. Subpoena Power and Production of Documents.-- In general.--The officer of any agency or department to whom the President has delegated any authority under this section, may-- examine any books, papers, records, or other data of any person which is relevant to the enforcement of this section or to any recordkeeping or reporting requirement prescribed for the purpose of carrying out this section; and summon any person, an officer or employee of any person (including a former officer or employee), or any person having possession, custody, or care of the reports and records required to be made or maintained pursuant to this section, to appear at a time and place named in the summons and to produce such books, papers, records, or other data, and to give testimony, under oath, as may be relevant or material to an investigation or procedure under this section. Administrative aspects of summons.-- Production at designated site.--A summons issued pursuant to this section may require that books, papers, records, or other data stored or maintained at any place be produced at any designated location in any State or in any territory or other place subject to the jurisdiction of the United States not more than 500 miles distant from any place where the person summoned operates or conducts business in the United States. Fees and travel expenses.--Persons summoned under this section shall be paid the same fees and mileage for travel in the United States that are paid witnesses in the courts of the United States. No liability for expenses.--The United States shall not be liable for any expense, other than an expense described in subparagraph , incurred in connection with the production of books, papers, records, or other data under this section. Service of summons.--Service of a summons issued under this section may be by registered mail or in such other manner calculated to give actual notice as the officer delegated by the President may prescribe by regulation. Contumacy or refusal.-- Referral to attorney general.--In case of contumacy by a person issued a summons under this subsection or a refusal by such person to obey such summons, the officer issuing the summons shall refer the matter to the Attorney General. Jurisdiction of court.--The Attorney General may invoke the aid of any court of the United States within the jurisdiction of which-- the investigation which gave rise to the summons is being or has been carried on; the person summoned is an inhabitant; or the person summoned carries on business or may be found, to compel compliance with the summons. Court order.--The court may issue an order requiring the person summoned to appear before the Secretary or his delegate to produce books, papers, records, and other data, to give testimony as may be necessary to explain how such material was compiled and maintained, and to pay the costs of the proceeding. Failure to comply with order.--Any failure to obey the order of the court may be punished by the court as a contempt thereof. Service of process.--All process in any case under this subsection may be served in any judicial district in which such person may be found. Injunctions and Other Relief.-- In general.--Whenever it appears to the officer authorized by the President to exercise authority under this Act, that any person has engaged, is engaged, or is about to engage in any act or practice that constitutes a violation of any regulation or order prescribed or issued pursuant to section 3, the officer may request the Attorney General to bring an action in an appropriate district court of the United States to enjoin such act or practice. Remedies.--Upon a proper showing in any action under paragraph , the court-- shall issue a temporary restraining order or grant a preliminary or permanent injunction without bond; may also issue a mandatory injunction commanding any person to comply with any order or injunction issued or granted under subparagraph ; and may order restitution of moneys received in violation of any regulation prescribed or order issued under section 3 or any order issued or injunction granted under this section. Penalties.-- Criminal.--Whoever knowingly violates any regulation prescribed or order issued under section 3 shall be fined not more than the amount equal to 200 percent of the amount of the sale related to each violation. Civil.-- In general.--Whoever violates any regulation prescribed or order issued under section 3 shall be liable to the United States for a civil penalty of not more than 200 percent of the amount by which such person was unjustly enriched in connection with such violation. Continuing violations.--A separate violation occurs for each sale of a pharmaceutical product in violation of a regulation prescribed or order issued under section 3. Assessment.-- Written notice.--Any penalty imposed under subparagraph may be assessed and collected by the officer authorized by the President to exercise authority under this Act by written notice. Finality of assessment.--If, with respect to any assessment under clause , a hearing is not requested pursuant to subparagraph within the period of time allowed under such subparagraph, the assessment shall constitute a final and unappealable order. Authority to modify or remit penalty.--Any officer authorized by the President to exercise authority under this Act may compromise, modify, or remit any penalty which such officer may assess or had already assessed under subparagraph . Mitigating factors.--In determining the amount of any penalty imposed under subparagraph , the officer authorized by the President to exercise authority under this Act shall take into account the appropriateness of the penalty with respect to-- the size of financial resources and good faith of the person charged; the gravity of the violation; the history of previous violations; and such other matters as justice may require. Hearing.--The person against whom any penalty is assessed under this paragraph shall be afforded an agency hearing if such person submits a request for such hearing within 20 days after the issuance of the notice of assessment. Collection.-- Referral.--If any person fails to pay an assessment after any penalty assessed under this paragraph has become final, the officer who imposed the penalty shall recover the amount assessed by action in the appropriate United States district court. Appropriateness of penalty not reviewable.--In any civil action under clause , the validity and appropriateness of the penalty shall not be subject to review. Disbursement.--All penalties collected under authority of this paragraph shall be deposited into the Treasury. Regulations.--Any officer authorized by the President to exercise authority under this Act shall prescribe regulations establishing such procedures as may be necessary to carry out this paragraph. Liability Established.--Any person who violates any regulation prescribed or order issued under this Act with respect to any other person shall be liable to such person in an amount equal to the sum of the amounts determined under each of the following paragraphs: Actual damages.--The greater of-- the amount of any actual damage sustained by such person as a result of such failure; or any amount paid by the injured person to the violator. Punitive damages.-- Individual actions.--In the case of any action by an individual, such additional amount as the court may allow. Class actions.--In the case of a class action, the sum of-- the aggregate of the amount which the court may allow for each named plaintiff; and the aggregate of the amount which the court may allow for each other class member, without regard to any minimum individual recovery. Attorneys' fees.--In the case of any successful action to enforce any liability under paragraph or , the costs of the action, together with reasonable attorneys' fees. Factors To Be Considered in Awarding Punitive Damages.--In determining the amount of any liability of any person under section , the court shall consider, among other relevant factors-- the frequency and persistence of noncompliance by the violator; the nature of the noncompliance; the extent to which such noncompliance was intentional; and in the case of any class action, the number of consumers adversely affected. There are authorized to be appropriated to the President for fiscal years 2003, 2004, and 2005, such sums as may be necessary to carry out this Act."</BILL><SUMMARY>Pharmaceutical Products Price Equity Act - Directs the Congress to regulate the pricing of American pharmaceutical products.Authorizes the President to delegate the performance of any function under this Act to any officer of any Federal department or agency who has been appointed by the President.Authorizes summonses and summonses to: (1) produce books, papers, records, or other data at designated locations in any designated location in any State  or in any territory or other place subject to such such jurisdiction, and to give testimony, under oath, as required by such law.Directs the Attorney General to invoke the aid of any court of the United States within the jurisdiction of which the summons is being or has been carried on.Authorizes the Attorney General to bring an action in any district in which such person may be found to have engaged in any act or practice that constitutes a violation of this Act.Sets forth criminal penalties for each violation of a regulation prescribed or order issued under this Act.Authorizes the President to exercise authority under this Act to: (1) compromise, modify, or remit a penalty; (2) impose a maximum penalty for such violation; (3) impose penalties on violators who do not respond within specified specified time frames; and (4) determine penalties for violations of the Act's prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.Requires an officer to prescribe regulations establishing such procedures as may be necessary.Requires the Court to award punitive damages, the greater the actual damage sustained by such person as a result of such failure, or the amount of punitive damages.Directs the President to make appropriations for FY2003-FY2005.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.1053629219532013</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>43</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Prepaid Card Consumer Protection Act of 2010''. Definition of ``Account''.--Section 903 of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693a) is amended by striking paragraph and inserting the following: ``the term `account'-- ``means-- ``a demand deposit, savings deposit, or other asset account (other than an occasional or incidental credit balance in an open end credit plan as defined in section 103of this Act), as described in regulations of the Bureau, established primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, including a payroll card account, as defined by the Bureau by rule; and ``a spending card account, as defined in section 924; and ``does not include an account held by a financial institution pursuant to a bona fide trust agreement;''. Definition of ``Financial Institution''.--Section 903of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693a) is amended by striking ``holds an account'' and inserting ``provides or holds an account containing funds''. Technical and Conforming Amendments.--Section 903 of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693a) is amended-- by redesignating paragraph (relating to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System), as so designated by section 1084of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203; 124 Stat. 2081), as paragraph ; and in paragraph , as so redesignated by paragraph of this subsection, by striking ``term `Bureau' means the Bureau of Governors'' and inserting ``term `Board' means the Board of Governors''. Spending Card Accounts.--The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693 et seq.) is amended-- by redesignating section 923 (15 U.S.C. 1693 note), relating to the effective date of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act, as so designated by section 1073 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203; 124 Stat. 2060), as section 925; by redesignating section 922 (15 U.S.C. 1693r), relating to exemptions for State regulation, as so designated by section 1073 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203; 124 Stat. 2060), as section 923; and by inserting after section 923, as redesignated by paragraph , the following: ``Sec. 924. Spending card accounts ``Definition.--For purposes of this section, the term `spending card account'-- ``means an asset account, other than as defined in subparagraph or of section 903-- ``that is established by a consumer or on behalf of a consumer; ``that contains the funds of a consumer; ``to which payments are to be made by a consumer, or at the direction of a consumer; ``to which recurring electronic fund transfers may be made, at the direction of a consumer; or ``from which payments may be made at the direction of a consumer through the use of a card, code, or device; ``includes an asset account described in paragraph -- ``that is operated or managed by a financial institution, or any other person; and ``the funds of which are-- ``pooled with the funds of a person other than the person who established the account; or ``held in a name other than that of the person who established the account; and ``does not include-- ``a nonreloadable general-use prepaid card, as defined in section 915, in an amount that does not exceed $250; ``a general-use prepaid card, as defined in section 915, that is solely associated with-- ``a health plan to which section 105 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies; ``a qualified transportation fringe, as defined in section 132of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; ``a health savings account, as defined in section 223of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; or ``any other healthcare benefit account, including a healthcare account relating to Medicare or Medicaid benefits; ``a gift certificate, as defined in section 915; ``a store gift card, as defined in section 915; ``an electronic promise, plastic card, or payment code or device described in clause , , or of section 915; ``a nonreloadable card labeled as a gift card and marketed solely as a gift card; or ``a nonreloadable loyalty, rebate or promotional card. ``FDIC Insurance.-- ``Insurance required.--A financial institution may only offer electronic fund transfer services in connection with a spending card account if the account is insured under, and complies with the requirements for pass-through deposit insurance under, section 11 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (12 U.S.C. 1821). ``Transfer of funds.--Any person that accepts funds in connection with an electronic fund transfer to a spending card account shall promptly, and in no event later than 24 hours after the person accepts the funds-- ``transfer such funds to an account at an insured depository institution (as defined in section 3of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (12 U.S.C. 1813)); or ``credit the spending card account an amount equal to the amount of such funds. ``Alternative to Periodic Statement.-- ``Periodic statement not required.--In the case of an electronic fund transfer from a spending card account, a financial institution shall not be subject to the requirement under section 906to provide a periodic statement to a consumer, if-- ``the financial institution provides to the consumer-- ``access to the account balance of the consumer-- ``through a readily available telephone line; ``through the Internet; and ``at an electronic terminal or other device that allows the consumer to make a balance inquiry, by providing balance information or, routinely or upon request, on a receipt provided at the electronic terminal at the time of an electronic fund transfer; ``notice of the means by which the consumer may access the account balance of the consumer, including any telephone number; ``in response to an oral or written request of the consumer, a written record of the account transactions of the consumer during the 2-year period ending on the date of the request that includes the information required to be provided to the consumer under section 906; ``an electronic record, such as a record available on the Internet, of the account transactions of the consumer during the 60-day period ending on the date on which the consumer accesses the electronic record that includes the information required to be provided to the consumer under section 906; ``with at least the same frequency as a written periodic statement that would otherwise be required under section 906, notification by email of the availability of an electronic history or an electronic periodic statement, unless the consumer has declined to provide an email address; ``the option to receive a written periodic statement and notice of such option; ``annual notice of the error resolution procedure for the spending card account, as prescribed in regulations of the Bureau; and ``any other transaction information that the financial institution elects to make available and that the consumer elects to receive, such as messages or alerts concerning balance levels or account activity; or ``the consumer does not provide a valid address to the card issuer. ``Fees prohibited.-- ``In general.--Except as provided in subparagraph , a financial institution may not charge a fee for any service provided under paragraph . ``Fee for written periodic statement.--A financial institution may charge a fee of not more than $1 for each written periodic statement provided under paragraph . ``No election by consumer.--If a consumer does not provide an email address to a financial institution and does not elect to receive written periodic statements under paragraph , the financial institution shall provide a written statement to the consumer at least once each year, at no cost to the consumer, that contains the date, source, and amount of each transaction made or fee charged, together with such additional information as the Bureau may require. ``Limitations on Liability.--For purposes of section 909, reimbursement need not be made to a consumer for a loss relating to a spending card account that a financial institution establishes would not have occurred but for the failure of the consumer to report any unauthorized electronic fund transfer or account error-- ``not later than 60 days after the earlier of-- ``the receipt by the consumer of a written account record under subsection that includes the unauthorized electronic fund transfer or account error; or ``the date on which account information that includes the unauthorized electronic fund transfer or account error is provided to or accessed by the consumer under subsection ; or ``in extenuating circumstances, such as extended travel or hospitalization, within a longer time that is reasonable under the circumstances. ``Fees.-- ``Fees prohibited.--Except as provided in paragraph , a financial institution may not charge in connection with a spending card account-- ``an annual fee; ``an overdraft fee, including a fee for shortage or nonsufficient funds, or any other fee for a transaction processed for amounts exceeding the account balance; ``a usage fee for use at the point of sale; ``a fee for a declined transaction; ``a fee for the use of an electronic terminal that is in the network of the issuer; ``an inactivity or dormancy fee; ``a fee for a balance inquiry or access to transaction information; ``a fee for an inquiry to customer service; ``a finance charge or other fee imposed in connection with an extension of credit; ``an account closing fee or a fee to obtain the remaining balance in the spending card account; or ``a fee for any activity not described in paragraph . ``Fees permitted.--A financial institution may charge in connection with a spending card account-- ``a fee for a replacement card-- ``of not more than $5 for the first replacement card requested by a consumer during any 12-month period; and ``that is in addition to the replacement card described in clause ; ``a fee for expedited delivery of a replacement card; ``a periodic fee, not more frequently than monthly; ``a reload fee, or any other fee for adding value to the spending card account, if the financial institution provides an alternate method for adding value to the spending card account without a fee; ``a fee for a transfer from the spending card account to another account; ``a fee for bill payment by check; ``a fee for a withdrawal by the consumer from an electronic terminal that is-- ``located outside the United States; ``not in the network of the financial institution, including a fee to cover the costs of any charge to the financial institution by the owner of the electronic terminal relating to the use of the electronic terminal by the consumer; ``a fee for a purchase or a withdrawal in a foreign currency; and ``an activation, initiation, or enrollment fee. ``Disclosure of fee information.-- ``Disclosure required.--Each financial institution that offers a spending card account shall provide to a consumer-- ``together with any application, offer, or solicitation for a spending card account-- ``a table of any fees that may be charged in connection with the spending card account that-- ``can be easily understood by the consumer; ``is conspicuously displayed to the consumer before purchase; and ``includes, at a minimum, the amount and a description of each fee that may be charged by the financial institution under paragraph ; and ``an estimate of the average total monthly cost to a typical consumer for using the spending card account; ``on the card or other means of access, a toll-free telephone number and website at which the consumer may access a clear and conspicuous disclosure of the fees that may be charged in connection with the spending card account; and ``a wallet-sized summary of any fees that may be charged in connection with the spending card account and a toll-free telephone number for customer service relating to the spending card account. ``Regulations.--Not later than 9 months after the date of enactment of the Prepaid Card Consumer Protection Act of 2010, the Bureau shall establish, by regulation-- ``the headings, content, and format of the fee table, estimate, and wallet-sized fee summary required under subparagraph ; and ``a profile of the typical consumer for purposes of subparagraph .''. Technical and Conforming Amendments.-- Written periodic statements.--Section 906of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693d) is amended, in the first sentence of the matter preceding paragraph , by striking ``A financial'' and inserting ``Except as provided in section 923, a financial''. Error resolution.--Section 908of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693f) is amended by striking ``or notification pursuant to section 906'' and inserting ``, notification pursuant to section 906, or written or electronic documentation pursuant to section 923''. This Act, and the amendments made by this Act, shall take effect on the date that is 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act."</BILL><SUMMARY>The Payment Card Consumer Protection Act of 2010 - Amends the Federal money transfer law to authorize the Federal transfer of funds to the principal owners of specified accounts, including a demand deposit, savings deposit, or other asset account (other than an occasional or incidental credit balance in an open end credit plan), to such an extent as to not include an account held by a financial institution pursuant to a bona fide trust agreement.Amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act to: (1) make the Federal Reserve Board of Governors the primary account holder for Federal Reserve funds; and (2) require the Federal Register of Federal Reserve accounts to be transferred to such a board.Amends the Consumer Protection Act of 1974 to prohibit the use of an asset account (the "spending card account") for purposes other than making payments to a consumer at the direction of a consumer, or for making electronic funds for such consumer.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to authorize the purchase of: (1) a nonreloadable general-use prepaid card ($250) that is solely associated with a health plan to which the person who established the account applies; (2) a qualified transportation fringe, as defined in section 132 (f) of the Internal revenue code; (3) an electronic promise, plastic card, or health savings account (HSBC) to be used as a healthcare account; (4) a gift certificate, a store gift card, an electronic pledge, or any other healthcare benefit account (Medicaid) to which such person shall not be entitled.Directs a financial institution to: (1) offer electronic fund transfer services in connection with a spending card account if the account is insured under, and complies with, pass-through deposit insurance requirements; or (2) transfer such funds to an account at an insured depository institution (as defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act).Requires a financial institution to: (1) provide to the consumer access to the account balance, including any telephone number; (2) in response to an oral or written question; (3) at an electronic terminal or other device that allows the consumer to make a balance inquiry; (4) at the time of an electronic fund transfer; (5) at such a device, by which the consumer may access account balance; (6) at a readily available telephone line; (7) at any electronic terminal, or (8) at whichever electronic terminal is available, by providing balance information or, routinely or upon request, on a receipt provided at the electronic terminal at such terminal at time of such transfer; and (8); (9) at least once a year, by making a written or oral statement to such institution of record. Requires such an institution to provide to consumers a written statement describing the means by which they may access the account account balance.Directs the bureau to provide: (1) with at least the same frequency as a written periodic statement that would otherwise be required under the Act; (2) notification by email of the availability of an electronic history or electronic periodic statement, unless the consumer declines to provide an email address; (3) notice of the error resolution procedure for the spending card account; and (4) any other transaction information that the financial institution elects to make available and that the consumer elects not to provide such information.Requires a financial institution to provide at least once a year a written periodic statement that contains the date, source, and amount of each transaction charged, together with such additional information as the bureau may require.Requires a financial institution to discontinue charging in connection with a spending card account for: (1) unauthorized electronic fund transfer or account error; or (2) in extenuating circumstances, such as extended travel or hospitalization.Requires a financial institution to charge a fee in connection with a spending card account for: (1) an inactivity or dormancy fee; (2) a fee for a balance inquiry or access to transaction information; (3) a finance charge or other fee that is in addition to the replacement card; (4) an account closing fee or a fee to obtain the remaining balance in the account; (5) a periodic fee, not more frequently than monthly; and (6) a reload fee, or any other fee for adding value to the spending card without a fee.Requires each financial institution that offers a spending card account to provide to a consumer a table of all fees that may be charged in connection with the use of the card account.Requires the Bureau to establish, by regulation, a fee table, estimate, and format for each fee that may be charged in connection with the account and a profile of the typical consumer.Electronic Fund Transfer Act - (Sec. 4) Amends the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Act to require the electronic fund transfer act to: (1) prohibit the transfer of funds to and from the Federal Reserve (FedEx); (2) require the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress on the status of such funds and to make such transfers available to the appropriate authorities; and (3) require such authorities to carry out such procedures.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.4345960319042206</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>44</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002''. This Act.--The purposes of this Act are-- to reauthorize the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.); and to ensure that the people and businesses of the Appalachian region have the knowledge, skills, and access to telecommunication and technology services necessary to compete in the knowledge-based economy of the United States. Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965.--Section 2 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.) is amended-- in subsection , by inserting after the third sentence the following: ``Consistent with the goal described in the preceding sentence, the Appalachian region should be able to take advantage of eco-industrial development, which promotes both employment and economic growth and the preservation of natural resources.''; and in subsection , by inserting ``, including eco-industrial development technologies'' before the semicolon. Section 102of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.) is amended-- in paragraph , by inserting ``, and support,'' after ``formation of''; in paragraph , by striking ``and'' at the end; in paragraph , by striking the period at the end and inserting a semicolon; and by adding at the end the following: ``encourage the use of eco-industrial development technologies and approaches; and ``seek to coordinate the economic development activities of, and the use of economic development resources by, Federal agencies in the region.''. Section 104 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.) is amended-- by striking ``The President'' and inserting ``In General.--The President''; and by adding at the end the following: ``Interagency Coordinating Council on Appalachia.-- ``Establishment.--In carrying out subsection , the President shall establish an interagency council to be known as the `Interagency Coordinating Council on Appalachia'. ``Membership.--The Council shall be composed of-- ``the Federal Cochairman, who shall serve as Chairperson of the Council; and ``representatives of Federal agencies that carry out economic development programs in the region.''. Title II of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.) is amended by inserting after section 202 the following: `` ``In General.--The Commission may provide technical assistance, make grants, enter into contracts, or otherwise provide funds to persons or entities in the region for projects-- ``to increase affordable access to advanced telecommunications, entrepreneurship, and management technologies or applications in the region; ``to provide education and training in the use of telecommunications and technology; ``to develop programs to increase the readiness of industry groups and businesses in the region to engage in electronic commerce; or ``to support entrepreneurial opportunities for businesses in the information technology sector. ``Source of Funding.-- ``In general.--Assistance under this section may be provided-- ``exclusively from amounts made available to carry out this section; or ``from amounts made available to carry out this section in combination with amounts made available under any other Federal program or from any other source. ``Federal share requirements specified in other laws.-- Notwithstanding any provision of law limiting the Federal share under any other Federal program, amounts made available to carry out this section may be used to increase that Federal share, as the Commission determines to be appropriate. ``Cost Sharing for Grants.--Not more than 50 percent (or 80 percent in the case of a project to be carried out in a county for which a distressed county designation is in effect under section 226) of the costs of any activity eligible for a grant under this section may be provided from funds appropriated to carry out this section.''. Title II of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.) is amended by inserting after section 203 (as added by section 5) the following: `` ``Definition of Business Incubator Service.--In this section, the term `business incubator service' means a professional or technical service necessary for the initiation and initial sustainment of the operations of a newly established business, including a service such as-- ``a legal service, including aid in preparing a corporate charter, partnership agreement, or basic contract; ``a service in support of the protection of intellectual property through a patent, a trademark, or any other means; ``a service in support of the acquisition and use of advanced technology, including the use of Internet services and Web-based services; and ``consultation on strategic planning, marketing, or advertising. ``Projects To Be Assisted.--The Commission may provide technical assistance, make grants, enter into contracts, or otherwise provide funds to persons or entities in the region for projects-- ``to support the advancement of, and provide, entrepreneurial training and education for youths, students, and businesspersons; ``to improve access to debt and equity capital by such means as facilitating the establishment of development venture capital funds; ``to aid communities in identifying, developing, and implementing development strategies for various sectors of the economy; and ``to develop a working network of business incubators; and ``to support entities that provide business incubator services. ``Source of Funding.-- ``In general.--Assistance under this section may be provided-- ``exclusively from amounts made available to carry out this section; or ``from amounts made available to carry out this section in combination with amounts made available under any other Federal program or from any other source. ``Federal share requirements specified in other laws.-- Notwithstanding any provision of law limiting the Federal share under any other Federal program, amounts made available to carry out this section may be used to increase that Federal share, as the Commission determines to be appropriate. ``Cost Sharing for Grants.--Not more than 50 percent (or 80 percent in the case of a project to be carried out in a county for which a distressed county designation is in effect under section 226) of the costs of any activity eligible for a grant under this section may be provided from funds appropriated to carry out this section.''. Title II of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 (40 U.S.C. App.) is amended by inserting after section 204 (as added by section 6) the following: `` ``Definition of Eligible Entity.--In this section, the term `eligible entity' means a consortium that-- ``is established to serve 1 or more industries in a specified geographic area; and ``consists of representatives of-- ``businesses (or a nonprofit organization that represents businesses); ``labor organizations; ``State and local governments; or ``educational institutions. ``Projects To Be Assisted.--The Commission may provide technical assistance, make grants, enter into contracts, or otherwise provide funds to eligible entities in the region for projects to improve the job skills of workers for a specified industry, including projects for-- ``the assessment of training and job skill needs for the industry; ``the development of curricula and training methods, including, in appropriate cases, electronic learning or technology- based training; ``the identification of training providers; and ``the development of partnerships between the industry and educational institutions, including community colleges; ``the development of apprenticeship programs; ``the development of training programs for workers, including dislocated workers; and ``the development of training plans for businesses. ``Administrative Costs.--An eligible entity may use not more than 10 percent of the funds made available to the eligible entity under subsection to pay administrative costs associated with the projects described in subsection . ``Source of Funding.-- ``In general.--Assistance under this section may be provided-- ``exclusively from amounts made available to carry out this section; or ``from amounts made available to carry out this section in combination with amounts made available under any other Federal program or from any other source. ``Federal share requirements specified in other laws.-- Notwithstanding any provision of law limiting the Federal share under any other Federal program, amounts made available to carry out this section may be used to increase that Federal share, as the Commission determines to be appropriate. ``Cost Sharing for Grants.--Not more than 50 percent (or 80 percent in the case of a project to be carried out in a county for which a distressed county designation is in effect under section 226) of the costs of any activity eligible for a grant under this section may be provided from funds appropriated to carry out this section.''. Speaker of the House of Representatives. Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate."</BILL><SUMMARY>Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002 - Amends the Appalachian Region Development Act of 1965 to allow the Appalachian region to take advantage of eco-industrial development, which promotes both employment and economic growth and the preservation of natural resources.Amends the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 to: (1) extend the authority of the Commission on the Indian Ocean and Caribbean Seas to include the President; (2) encourage the use of eco-development technologies and approaches; and (3) seek to coordinate the economic development activities of federal agencies in the region.
