<ROW>81</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Open Our Democracy Act of 2014''. PRIMARIES. Rules for Election of House Members.--A candidate for election for the office of Member of the House of Representatives shall be elected to such office pursuant to the following elections held by the State in which the candidate seeks election: A single open primary election for such office held in accordance with subsection . A single general election for such office held in accordance with subsection . Open Primaries.--Each State shall hold a single open primary election for each office of Member of the House of Representatives in the State under which-- each candidate for such office, regardless of the candidate's political party preference, shall appear on a single ballot; and each voter in the State who is eligible to vote in elections for Federal office in the Congressional district involved may cast a ballot in the election, regardless of the voter's political party preference. General Election.--Each State shall hold a general election for each office of Member of the House of Representatives in the State under which the 2 candidates receiving the greatest number of votes in the single open primary election for such office (as described in subsection ), without regard to the political party preference of such candidates, shall be the only candidates appearing on the ballot. Option of Candidates To Declare Political Party Preference.--At the time a candidate for the office of Member of the House of Representatives files to run for such office, the candidate shall have the option of declaring a political party preference, and the preference chosen (if any) shall accompany the candidate's name on the ballot for the election for such office. Designation for Candidates Not Declaring Preference.--If a candidate does not declare a political party preference under subsection , the designation ``No Party Preference'' shall accompany the candidate's name on the ballot for the election for such office. No Party Endorsement Implied.--The selection of a party preference by a candidate under subsection shall not constitute or imply endorsement of the candidate by the party designated, and no candidate in a general election shall be deemed the official candidate of any party by virtue of his or her selection in the primary. Nothing in this Act shall restrict the right of individuals to join or organize into political parties or in any way restrict the right of private association of political parties. Nothing in this Act shall restrict a party's right to contribute to, endorse, or otherwise support a candidate for the office of Member of the House of Representatives. A political party may establish such procedures as it sees fit to endorse or support candidates or otherwise participate in all elections, and may informally designate candidates for election to such an office at a party convention or by whatever lawful mechanism the party may choose, other than pursuant to a primary election held by a State. A political party may also adopt such rules as it sees fit for the selection of party officials (including central committee members, presidential electors, and party officers), including rules restricting participation in elections for party officials to those who disclose a preference for that party at the time of registering to vote. HOLIDAY FOR PURPOSES OF FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT. In General.--For purposes of any law relating to Federal employment, the Tuesday next after the first Monday in November in 2016 and each even-numbered year thereafter shall be treated in the same manner as a legal public holiday described in section 6103 of title 5, United States Code. Sense of Congress Regarding Treatment of Day by Private Employers.--It is the sense of Congress that private employers in the United States should give their employees a day off on the Tuesday next after the first Monday in November in 2016 and each even-numbered year thereafter to enable the employees to cast votes in the elections held on that day. REDISTRICTING. Study.--The Comptroller General shall conduct a study of the feasibility and desirability of enacting national standards and criteria for Congressional redistricting. Report to Congress.--Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit a report to Congress on the study conducted under subsection . ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 7.5.......................................... Before January 1, 1999. 7.75........................................ January 1, 1999, to December 31, 1999. 7.9......................................... January 1, 2000, to December 31, 2000. 7.55........................................ After January 11, 2003. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In this Act, the term ``Member of the House of Representatives'' included a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to the Congress. Except as provided in sections 5and 6, this Act shall apply with respect to elections occurring during 2016 or any succeeding year."</BILL><SUMMARY>Open Our Democracy Act of 2014 - Directs each state to hold a single open primary election for each office of the House of Representatives in order to elect its members to federal office.Directs a political party to establish procedures as it sees fit to endorse or support candidates or otherwise participate in all elections, and to informally designate candidates for election to such an office at a party convention or by whatever lawful mechanism the party may choose, other than a primary election.Directs the Comptroller General to conduct a study of the feasibility and desirability of enacting national standards and criteria for congressional redistricting.Directs the Speaker to appoint a delegate or resident commissioner to the Congress.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.07483992725610733</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>82</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Twenty-First Amendment Enforcement Act''. STATE LAW. The Act entitled ``An Act divesting intoxicating liquors of their interstate character in certain cases'', approved March 1, 1913 (commonly known as the ``Webb-Kenyon Act'') (27 U.S.C. 122) is amended by adding at the end the following: `` ``Definitions.--In this section-- ``the term `attorney general' means the attorney general or other chief law enforcement officer of a State, or the designee thereof; ``the term `intoxicating liquor' means any spirituous, vinous, malted, fermented, or other intoxicating liquor of any kind; ``the term `person' means any individual and any partnership, corporation, company, firm, society, association, joint stock company, trust, or other entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property, but does not include a State or agency thereof; and ``the term `State' means any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, or any territory or possession of the United States. ``Action by State Attorney General.--If the attorney general has reasonable cause to believe that a person is engaged in, or has engaged in, any act that would constitute a violation of a State law regulating the importation or transportation of any intoxicating liquor, the attorney general may bring a civil action in accordance with this section for injunctive relief (including a preliminary or permanent injunction or other order) against the person, as the attorney general determines to be necessary to-- ``restrain the person from engaging, or continuing to engage, in the violation; and ``enforce compliance with the State law. ``Federal Jurisdiction.-- ``In general.--The district courts of the United States shall have jurisdiction over any action brought under this section by an attorney general against any person, except one licensed or otherwise authorized to produce, sell, or store intoxicating liquor in such State. ``Venue.--An action under this section may be brought only in accordance with section 1391 of title 28, United States Code, or in the district in which the recipient of the intoxicating liquor resides or is found. ``Requirements for Injunctions and Orders.-- ``In general.--In any action brought under this section, upon a proper showing by the attorney general of the State, the court may issue a preliminary or permanent injunction or other order to restrain a violation of this section. A proper showing under this paragraph shall require clear and convincing evidence that a violation of State law as described in subsection has taken place. In addition, no temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction may be granted except upon-- ``evidence demonstrating the probability of irreparable injury if injunctive relief is not granted; and ``evidence supporting the probability of success on the merits. ``Notice.--No preliminary injunction or permanent injunction or other order may be issued under paragraph without notice to the adverse party and an opportunity for a hearing. ``Form and scope of order.--Any preliminary or permanent injunction or other order entered in an action brought under this section shall-- ``set forth the reasons for the issuance of the order; ``be specific in its terms; ``describe in reasonable detail, and not by reference to the complaint or other document, the act or acts sought to be restrained; and ``be binding upon-- ``the parties to the action and the officers, agents, employees, and attorneys of those parties; and ``persons in active concert or participation with the parties to the action who receive actual notice of the order by personal service or otherwise. ``Additional Remedies.-- ``In general.--A remedy under this section is in addition to any other remedies provided by law. ``State court proceedings.--Nothing in this section may be construed to prohibit an authorized State official from proceeding in State court on the basis of an alleged violation of any State law. `` ``Effect on Internet Tax Freedom Act.--Nothing in this Act may be construed to modify or supersede the operation of the Internet Tax Freedom Act (47 U.S.C. 151 note). ``Enforcement of Twenty-First Amendment.--It is the purpose of this Act to assist the States in the enforcement of section 2 of the twenty-first article of amendment to the Constitution of the United States, and not to impose an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce in violation of article I, section 8, of the Constitution of the United States. No State may enforce under this Act a law regulating the importation or transportation of any intoxicating liquor that unconstitutionally discriminates against interstate commerce by out-of- State sellers by favoring local industries, erecting barriers to competition, and constituting mere economic protectionism. ``Support for Internet and Other Interstate Commerce.--Nothing in this Act may be construed-- ``to permit State regulation or taxation of Internet services or any other related interstate telecommunications services; or ``to authorize any injunction against-- ``an interactive computer service (as defined in section 230of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 230); or ``electronic communication service (as defined in section 2510of title 18, United States Code) used by another person to engage in any activity that is subject to this Act.''. Effective Date.--Except as provided in subsection , this Act and the amendment made by this Act shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. Application of Amendment.--The amendment made by this Act shall apply only with respect to the importation or transportation of any intoxicating liquor occurring after-- October 31, 1999, or the expiration of the 90-day period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act, whichever is earlier, if this Act is enacted before November 1, 1999; or the date of the enactment of this Act if this Act is enacted after October 31, 1999. The Attorney General shall submit to the Congress the results of a study to determine the impact of this Act. The Attorney General shall carry out the study required by subsection and shall submit the results of such study not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act. Passed the House of Representatives August 3, 1999. Attest: JEFF TRANDAHL, Clerk. By Martha C. Morrison, Deputy Clerk."</BILL><SUMMARY>The Kentucky First Amendment Enforcement Act  This bill amends the Webb-Kenyon Act to prohibit the import, sale, or transportation of intoxicating liquors of their interstate character without the Attorney General's approval or approval.Directs the Attorney General to bring a civil action against a person for: (1) violations of the State or Federal prohibition against the importation or transportation of intoxicating liquor; and (2) enforce compliance with such prohibition.Requires the court to issue a preliminary or permanent injunction or other order to restrain a violation of this Act if no such showing has taken place.Authorizes an authorized State official to proceed in state court on the basis of an alleged violation of state law.Directs the Attorney General to appoint an interagency commission to investigate whether the State may enforce a law regulating the importation or transportation of any intoxicating liquor that unconstitutionally discriminates against interstate commerce by out-of-state sellers by favoring local industries, erecting barriers to competition, and constituting mere economic protectionism. Authorizes the Attorney general to appoint a special commission to determine whether such a commission shall be authorized by the State Attorney General.Directs the Attorney General to carry out a study to determine the impact of this Act.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.16674718260765076</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>83</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Natural Gas Reserve Act of 2001''. Title I of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act is amended by-- redesignating part E as part F; redesignating section 191 as section 198; and inserting after part D the following new part E: ``Part E--Natural Gas Reserve ``establishment ``Sec. 191. Authority.--Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, the Secretary may establish, maintain, and operate a Natural Gas Reserve. The Reserve established under this part is not a component of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve established under part B of this title. ``Definition.--For the purposes of this part, the term `natural gas' has the meaning given that term in section 2of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 (15 U.S.C. 3301). ``authority ``Sec. 192. To the extent necessary or appropriate to carry out this part, the Secretary may-- ``purchase, contract for, lease, or otherwise acquire, in whole or in part, storage and related facilities, and storage services; ``use, lease, maintain, sell, or otherwise dispose of storage and related facilities acquired under this part; ``acquire by purchase, exchange (including exchange of petroleum products from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve or received as royalty from Federal lands), lease, or otherwise, natural gas for storage in the Natural Gas Reserve; ``store natural gas in facilities not owned by the United States; and ``sell, exchange, or otherwise dispose of natural gas from the Natural Gas Reserve, including to maintain the quality or quantity of the natural gas in the Reserve or to maintain the operational capability of the Reserve. ``conditions for release; plan ``Sec. 193. Finding.--The Secretary may sell products from the Natural Gas Reserve upon a finding that there is a natural gas supply shortage. ``Release of Natural Gas.--After consultation with the natural gas industry, the Secretary shall determine procedures governing the release of natural gas from the Natural Gas Reserve. The procedures shall provide that-- ``the Secretary may-- ``sell natural gas from the Reserve through a competitive process; or ``enter into exchange agreements described in section 192; ``in all such sales or exchanges, the Secretary shall receive revenue or its equivalent that provides the Department with fair market value; ``at no time may the natural gas be sold or exchanged resulting in a loss of revenue or value to the United States; and ``the Secretary shall only sell or dispose of the natural gas in the Reserve to entities customarily engaged in the sale and distribution of natural gas. ``Plan.--Within 45 days after the date of the enactment of this section, the Secretary shall transmit to the Congress a plan describing-- ``the acquisition of storage and related facilities or storage services for the Natural Gas Reserve, including the potential use of storage facilities not currently in use; ``the acquisition of natural gas for storage in the Natural Gas Reserve; ``the anticipated methods of disposition of natural gas from the Natural Gas Reserve; ``the estimated costs of establishment, maintenance, and operation of the Natural Gas Reserve; ``efforts the Department will take to minimize any potential need for future drawdowns and ensure that distributors and importers are not discouraged from maintaining and increasing supplies; and ``actions to ensure quality of the natural gas in the Natural Gas Reserve. ``natural gas reserve account ``Sec. 194. Establishment.--Upon a decision of the Secretary of Energy to establish a Natural Gas Reserve under this part, the Secretary of the Treasury shall establish in the Treasury of the United States an account known as the `Natural Gas Reserve Account' (referred to in this section as the `Account'). ``Deposits.--The Secretary of the Treasury shall deposit in the Account any amounts appropriated to the Account and any receipts from the sale, exchange, or other disposition of natural gas from the Natural Gas Reserve. ``Availability.--The Secretary of Energy may obligate amounts in the Account to carry out activities under this part without the need for further appropriation, and amounts available to the Secretary of Energy for obligation under this section shall remain available without fiscal year limitation. ``exemptions ``Sec. 195. An action taken under this part is not subject to the rulemaking requirements of section 523 of this Act, section 501 of the Department of Energy Organization Act, or section 553 of title 5, United States Code.''."</BILL><SUMMARY>Natural Gas Reserve Act of 2001 - Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish, maintain, and operate a natural gas reserve.Directs the Secretary to:  (1) use, lease, sell, or otherwise dispose of storage and related facilities acquired under the Strategic Petroleum Reserve; (2) acquire by purchase, exchange (including exchange of petroleum products from the Strategic petroleum Reserve or received as royalty from the United States), lease, otherwise, natural gas for storage in the National Gas Reserve; and (3) use such proceeds to: (1); develop, operate, and construct a new natural gas production facility; and, if necessary, construct a natural gas distribution line.Directs the Secretary to: (1) sell or dispose of the natural gas in the reserve to entities customarily engaged in the sale and distribution of natural gas; (2) enter into exchange agreements with entities that provide the Secretary with revenue or value; and (3) at no time may the Natural Gas be sold or exchanged resulting in a loss of revenue or valued to the United States.Directs the Secretary of Energy to establish in the Treasury of the United States an account known as the Natural Gas Reserve Account.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.9174749255180359</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>84</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Technology for the Classroom Act of 1993''. It is the purpose of this Act to establish a program to develop and expand the use of high quality curriculum-based learning resources using state-of-the-art technologies and techniques which are or can be designed to increase the achievement levels of students in subject areas including mathematics, science, geography, history and language arts. Competitive Grants.-- In general.--The Secretary shall award grants, on a competitive basis, to eligible consortia to enable such eligible consortia to develop instructional programs or technology-based systems for complete courses or units of study for a specific subject and grade level, if such programs or systems are commercially unavailable in the local area served by such eligible consortia. Eligible consortium.--For the purpose of this section the term ``eligible consortium'' means a consortium consisting of-- State or local educational agencies in partnership with businesses; and institutions of higher education or other public or private nonprofit organizations. Priority.--In awarding grants under this section, the Secretary shall give priority to applications describing programs or systems that are developed-- so that the program or system may be adapted and applied nationally; and to raise the achievement levels of students, particularly disadvantaged students who are not realizing their potential. Duration and Amount.--Each grant made under this section shall be awarded for a period not to exceed 3 years and in an amount not to exceed $3,000,000. Matching Requirement.--The Secretary may not make a grant to an eligible consortium under subsection unless the eligible consortium agrees that, with respect to the costs to be incurred by the eligible consortium in carrying out the program or system for which the grant was awarded, the eligible consortium will make available (from private sources) non-Federal contributions in an amount not less than 25 percent of the Federal funds provided under the grant. Application.-- In general.--Each consortium desiring a grant under this section shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and accompanied by such information as the Secretary may prescribe. Contents.--Each application submitted pursuant to paragraph shall include-- a description of how the program or system shall improve the achievement levels of students; a description of how teachers associated with the program or system will be trained to integrate technology into the classroom; and an assurance that the program or system shall effectively serve a large number or percentage of economically disadvantaged students. Criteria for Awarding Grants.--In awarding a grant under this section to develop a program or system, the Secretary shall consider the appropriateness and quality of the following elements of the program or system: Identification of specific learning objectives and strategies of the proposed course or unit of study, that take into consideration the national education standards for various disciplines as such standards are developed. Incorporation in creative ways of a variety of technology-based learning resources such as computer software, databases, films, transparencies, video and audio discs, telecommunications (including educational radio and television), and print materials. Design that allows tailoring of the program or system to meet individual needs of students, particularly students at greatest risk of not reaching their educational potential. Flexibility of use by teachers or local schools. Methods for updating or revising information and material. Programs or materials to train and guide teachers. Coordination with teacher training programs. Explanatory materials for students and parents. Field testing and evaluation in terms of stated learning objectives. Plans for pricing technology-based materials that are affordable for public schools and agencies. Plans for distribution that ensure access for the poorest schools and school districts. Demonstration of cost-effectiveness in relation to existing programs and to achieving stated learning objectives. Grants Authorized.-- In general.--The Secretary is authorized to award grants to States to enable States to carry out the activities described in the plan submitted pursuant to subsection . Amount of grant.--Except as provided in subparagraph , the Secretary shall award grants under this section to each State having a plan approved under subsection in an amount which bears the same relationship to the amount reserved to carry out this section under section 9 as the amount such State received under chapter 1 of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 bears to the amount received under such chapter by all States. No State shall receive a grant pursuant to subparagraph in an amount which is less than $100,000. Use of Grant.--Grants awarded under this section shall be used to-- identify schools or school districts which have a large number of educationally disadvantaged students and limited access to technology-based learning resources; and develop jointly, with local education agencies or individual schools, strategies to improve the accessibility and use of technology-based learning resources, including specific plans for-- training of teachers and school personnel; acquisition of hardware or software, if such acquisition presents a major barrier for accessibility to participation in the activities assisted under this section; and partnership arrangements with businesses, institutions of higher education, or other public or private nonprofit organizations. Plan.-- In general.--Each State desiring a grant under this section shall submit to the Secretary a plan at such time, in such manner and accompanied by such information as the Secretary may reasonably require. Contents.--Each plan submitted pursuant to paragraph shall-- describe the activities and services for which assistance is sought; indicate how such State shall identify schools in need of the assistance provided under this section; include a strategy for providing such assistance; and contain assurances that such grant funds shall be focused on schools with a large percentage of educationally disadvantaged students. The Secretary shall coordinate and share information regarding curriculum-based educational technology programs assisted under this Act with other Federal agencies which administer programs that support the development of such programs, including the National Science Foundation, the Department of Defense, the Office of Technology Assessment, the Department of Energy, and the Department of Agriculture. The Secretary shall collect information about products developed pursuant to provisions of this Act and the evaluation of such products, and shall disseminate such information in regular reports to State and local educational agencies, and other organizations or individuals as the Secretary determines to be appropriate. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, any royalties paid to any State or local educational agency as a result of assistance provided under this Act shall be used by such agency for further development of curriculum-based learning resources authorized by this Act. As used in this Act-- the terms ``institution of higher education'' and ``local educational agency'' have the same meanings given such terms by subsections and , respectively, of section 1201 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1141); and the term ``Secretary'', unless otherwise specified, means the Secretary of Education. For the purpose of carrying out this Act, there are authorized to be appropriated $90,000,000 for the fiscal year 1994 and such sums as may be necessary for each of the 4 succeeding fiscal years, of which-- 50 percent of such funds shall be available in each such fiscal year to award grants pursuant to section 3; and 50 percent of such funds shall be available in each such fiscal year to award grants pursuant to section 4."</BILL><SUMMARY>Technology for the Classroom Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Education to establish a program to develop and expand the use of high quality curriculum-based learning resources using state-of-the-art technologies and techniques which are or can be designed to increase the achievement levels of students in subject areas including mathematics, science, geography, history and language arts. Authorizes the Secretary to award grants to eligible consortia to develop instructional programs or technology-based systems for complete courses or units of study for a specific subject and grade level if such programs or systems are commercially unavailable in the local area served.Requires the Secretary of Education to give priority to applications describing programs or systems that are developed, so that the program or system may be adapted and applied nationally, and to raise the achievement levels of students who are not realizing their potential.Directs the Secretary to consider the appropriateness and quality of the program or system to improve the achievement levels of students, particularly students at greatest risk of not reaching their educational potential.Directs the Secretary to award grants to states to enable states to carry out specified activities.Requires each State desiring a grant under this Act to submit to the Secretary a plan describing the activities and services for which assistance is sought.Authorizes the Secretary of Education to allocate funds for the purposes of carrying out this Act.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.5643510222434998</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>85</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Frontline Medical Education Act''. QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER UNDER ANY PROGRAM PAID FOR BY A HOSPITAL IN DETERMINING MEDICARE PAYMENTS FOR GRADUATE MEDICAL EDUCATION. Payment for Direct Costs of Graduate Medical Education.-- Section 1886of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395ww) is amended by striking ``setting.'' and inserting the following: ``setting (or, in the case of activities performed at an Federally-qualified health center described in section 1861, if the hospital incurs any of the costs for the training program at such center and reimburses the center for any of the costs of the program that the center incurs).''. Payment for Indirect Costs of Graduate Medical Education.-- Section 1886of such Act (42 U.S.C. 1395ww), as amended by section 13506 of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993, is amended-- by striking ``entity receiving a grant'' and all that follows through ``control of the hospital'' and inserting ``Federally-qualified health center described in section 1861''; by striking ``all, or substantially all, of the costs'' and inserting ``any of the costs''; and by striking ``residents)'' and inserting ``residents and reimburses the center for any of the costs of the program that the center incurs)''. Effective Date.--The amendments made by subsections and shall apply to services furnished during cost reporting periods beginning on or after October 1, 1994. FEDERALLY-QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTERS. In General.--Title XVIII of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395 et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 1889 the following new section: ``graduate medical education payments for federally-qualified health centers ``Sec. 1890. In General.--Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, in the case of any Federally-qualified health center that participates in an approved medical residency training program, in addition to any other payments that may be made to the center under this title, the Secretary shall provide for payment to the center for direct graduate medical education costs in accordance with subsection . ``Determination of Amount of Payment.-- ``In general.--Subject to paragraph , the amount of payment made to a Federally-qualified health center under this section for direct medical education for a fiscal year is equal to the product of-- ``the aggregate approved amount (as defined in paragraph ) for the year; and ``the center's medicare patient load (as defined in subsection ) for the year. ``Aggregate approved amount.--In paragraph , the term `aggregate approved amount' means, for a fiscal year, the product of-- ``the approved FTE resident amount (determined under paragraph ) for the year; and ``the weighted average number of full-time equivalent residents (as determined by the Secretary in a manner similar to the manner used to determine the number of such residents under section 1886) providing services for the center under the approved medical residency training program in which the center participates during the year. ``Determination of approved fte resident amount.-- ``In general.--For each approved medical residency training program, the Secretary shall determine an approved FTE resident amount for each fiscal year (beginning with fiscal year 1995) equal to 250 percent of the national average salary for the year (as defined in subparagraph ). ``Determination of national average salary.-- ``Determination of base amount.--The Secretary shall determine a base salary amount equal to the Secretary's estimate (using the most recent available audited cost reports) of the national average salary, including fringe benefits, for a full-time-equivalent resident in an approved medical residency training program during fiscal year 1990, increased (in a compounded manner) by the sum of the estimated percentage changes in the consumer price index during the 12-month periods between the midpoint of fiscal year 1990 and the midpoint of fiscal year 1994. ``National average salary defined.--In this paragraph, the `national average salary' for a fiscal year is equal to-- ``for fiscal year 1995, the base amount determined under clause updated through the midpoint of the year by projecting the estimated percentage change in the consumer price index during the 12-month period ending at that midpoint (with appropriate adjustments to reflect previous under- or over-estimations under this subparagraph in the projected percentage change in the consumer price index); and ``for a subsequent fiscal year, the amount determined under this clause for the previous fiscal year updated through the midpoint of the year by projecting the estimated percentage change in the consumer price index during the 12-month period ending at that midpoint (with appropriate adjustments to reflect previous under- or over-estimations under this subparagraph in the projected percentage change in the consumer price index). ``Offset for reimbursement received directly through hospitals.--The amount of payment made to a Federally-qualified health center under this subsection with respect to costs incurred by the center shall be reduced by the amount of any payment received by the center from a hospital under section 1886or section 1886as reimbursement for such costs. ``Allocation of Payments Among Trust Funds.--In providing for payments under this section, the Secretary shall provide for an allocation of such payments between part A and part B (and the trust funds established under the respective parts) as reasonably reflects the proportion of direct graduate medical costs of Federally-qualified health centers associated with the provision of services under each respective part. ``Definitions.--In this section: ``The terms `approved medical residency training program', `consumer price index', `direct graduate medical education costs', and `resident' have the meaning given such terms under section 1886. ``The term `Federally-qualified health center' has the meaning given such term under section 1861. ``The term `medicare patient load' means, with respect to a Federally-qualified health center for a year, the fraction of the center's services during the year which are attributable to individuals entitled to benefits under this title (based on such measure of services as the Secretary determines to be appropriate for purposes of this section).''. Effective Date.--The amendment made by subsection shall apply to services furnished during cost reporting periods beginning on or after October 1, 1994. RECEIVING PAYMENTS FOR MEDICAL EDUCATION. Section 1861of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395x) is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph: ``In the case of a Federally-qualified health center receiving any medical education payment described in subparagraph during a cost reporting period, the Secretary shall waive the application of any screening guideline used to determine the productivity of practitioners providing services at the center for purposes of paragraph or . ``A medical education payment described in this subparagraph is a payment made to a Federally-qualified health center-- ``by a hospital as reimbursement to the center for medical education costs, as described in section 1886or section 1886; or ``by the Secretary under section 1890.''."</BILL><SUMMARY>Frontline Medical Education Act - Amends the Social Security Act to authorize payment for the costs of graduate medical education at any federally-qualified health center.Requires the Secretary to provide for payment for graduate medical education costs to a federally-qualified health center that participates in an approved medical residency training program.Requires the Secretary to determine an approved Fte resident amount for each approved medical residency training program.Requires the Secretary to determine a base salary amount equal to 250 percent of the national average salary for FY 1995.Requires the Secretary to: (1) reduce the amount of payment made to a federally-qualified health center (FICC) with respect to direct graduate medical costs incurred by such a center; and (2) provide for an allocation of such payments among trust funds established under this Act.Amends the Social Security Act to repeal the application of productivity screens for centers receiving payments for medical education.Requires the Secretary to waive the application of any screening guideline used to determine the productivity of practitioners providing services at the center.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.7355550527572632</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>86</ROW><BILL>"Short Title.--This Act may be cited as the ``Acquisition Savings Reform Act of 2011''. Table of Contents.--The table of contents for this Act is as follows: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents. Sec. 2. Definitions. Sec. 3. Use of reverse auction methods. Sec. 4. Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative. Sec. 5. Savings through leveraging the Federal Government's purchasing power. Sec. 6. Governmentwide contract vehicles. Sec. 7. Streamlining of contract closeouts. Sec. 8. Affordability as a requirement for certain acquisition plans. Sec. 9. Cost efficiency objectives for service contracts. Sec. 10. Establishing governmentwide acquisition savings criteria. Sec. 11. Office of Management and Budget savings requirements. Sec. 12. Expedited payment to small business. In this Act: Approved business case.--The term ``approved business case'' means a business case approved by the senior procurement executive of an executive agency. Acquisition.--The term ``acquisition'' has the meaning given the term in section 131 of title 41, United States Code. Commercial item.--The term ``commercial item'' has the meaning given the term in section 103 of title 41, United States Code. Executive agency.--The term ``executive agency'' has the meaning given the term in section 133 of title 41, United States Code. Federal acquisition regulation.--The term ``Federal Acquisition Regulation'' means the Federal Acquisition Regulation maintained under section 1303of title 41, United States Code. Federal acquisition regulatory council.--The term ``Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council'' means the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council established under section 1302of title 41, United States Code. Federal strategic sourcing vehicles .--The term ``Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles'' means a kind of governmentwide interagency acquisition contract or agreement designated by the Office of Management and Budget to leverage the Federal Government's buying power and save taxpayers money. Interagency contract.--The term ``interagency contract''-- includes-- governmentwide acquisition contracts as defined in Federal Acquisition Regulation part 2.101; multi-agency contracts as defined in Federal Acquisition Regulation part 2.101; Federal Supply Schedule contracts; and franchise funds; and does not include contracts entered into under the authority of section 1535 of title 31, United States Code. Procurement.--The term ``procurement'' has the meaning given the term in section 111 of title 41, United States Code. Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require the heads of executive agencies, to the extent possible, to use online reverse auction, or an equivalent method, in the procurement of commercial items above the simplified acquisition threshold whenever doing so would be expected to result in savings to the agencies. The regulatory guidance shall address the circumstances in which use of reverse auctions is appropriate, and shall direct agencies, in deciding whether to use auctions or an equivalent method, to consider the dollar volume of the acquisition and potential to streamline the procurement for the agency and vendors. Consideration in Acquisition Planning Process.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require the consideration of Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles in the acquisition planning process, by including a listing of Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles in the ``Priorities for use of Government supply sources'' for Supplies and Services. The Office of Management and Budget shall maintain a website with the current list of Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles. The Supplies priority shall be after the priority for wholesale supply services. The Services priority shall be after services which are on the Procurement List maintained by the Committee for Purchase From People Who are Blind or Severely Disabled. The Federal Acquisition Regulation shall be amended to authorize purchases from other than from Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles, provided that consideration is given to its use in the acquisition planning process. The plan will be documented to acknowledge why usage of other than Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles is warranted. The acknowledgment shall indicate that such action is judged to be in the best interest of the Federal Government in terms of the combination quality, timeliness, and cost that best meets the requirement. Cost comparisons shall include the administrative cost of the acquisition. Unusual and compelling urgency as prescribed in the Federal Acquisition Regulation shall also be an authorized reason from deviating from the Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles. Maximization of Small Business and Other Socioeconomic Categories in Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles.--The Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy shall issue policy maximizing the participation of small business and other socioeconomic categories such as service-disabled veteran-owned small business in these Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles. Agencies shall also be credited towards their small business goals when awarding to small business Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicle contract holders. Identification of Designated Federal Strategic Source Vehicles.--The Office of Management and Budget shall identify on its website a list of all Federal Strategic Source Vehicle contracts and agreements and awardees. Inclusion of Information Technology Purchases and Services in Initiative.-- Data collection.--The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall prescribe regulations requiring Chief Information Officers and Chief Acquisition Officers of executive agencies to develop and gather such data on information technology purchases and service acquisitions by North American Industrial Classification codes. Annual report.--The regulations prescribed under this subsection shall require the head of each executive agency to submit to the Director of Office of Management and Budget an annual report through fiscal year 2016 including the data collected under paragraph and a plan for the strategic sourcing of information technology purchases and common commercial services. The plan shall include specific milestones, measurable savings, and evaluation criteria. Reporting.--The head of each executive agency shall submit to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget an annual report for each of fiscal years 2013 through 2016, estimating the amount of savings achieved through the usage of Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles and through other measurable acquisition savings methods approved by the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy. The report shall also specify by each Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicle commodity what guidance the agency has issued to employees instructing them to procure goods or services through the Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicle. If the agency has not issued such guidance to their employees, the agency shall submit an explanation. POWER. Not later than 120 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall develop a plan to achieve not less than $1,000,000,000 in measurable savings through Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles for fiscal years 2013 through 2016. The plan shall include an annual scorecard measuring the success of each executive agency in achieving savings. Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to provide that-- where an agency is unable to satisfy the requirements from a mandatory source, agencies are strongly encouraged to utilize Federal Supply Schedules, governmentwide acquisition contracts, multi-agency contracts, and any other procurement instruments intended for use by multiple agencies, including blanket purchase agreements under Federal Supply Schedule contracts absent a written justification that the governmentwide contract is not in the best interest of the Federal Government; agencies shall promote acquisition strategies utilizing these vehicles to maximize participation of small businesses and other socioeconomic categories, including set-asides of acquisitions under these vehicles; and contracting officers shall be encouraged by agency guidance to maximize competition under these vehicles to the maximum amount practicable with the goal of achieving the best value to the Federal Government. Authority To Waive Contract Closeout Audits.-- Authority.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to provide contracting officers the authority to waive contract closeout audits above the simplified acquisition purchase threshold based on risk assessments. Factors upon which an assessment of low risk may include time and material contracts, low dollar cost type contracts, and contractors with approved business systems, strong internal controls, and good past performance ratings. Guidance.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy, in collaboration with the Director of the Defense Procurement and Acquisition Policy, shall issue guidance for assisting contracting officials in determining when waivers of contract closeout audits pursuant to paragraph are appropriate. Use of abilityone program.--Where practicable, and in accordance with the Javits-Wagner-O'Day Act (41 U.S.C. 46 et seq.) as administered by the Committee For Purchase From People Who Are Blind or Severely Disabled, utilize the AbilityOne Program to accomplish non-inherently governmental tasks associated with contract or grant close-out in those cases where a Federal agency utilizes contractor support for close- out functions. Firm-Fixed Contracts.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to provide that, on firm-fixed contracts-- contractors shall submit a final invoice within 60 days of Federal Government acceptance or relinquish payment unless exempted by the contracting officer; the contracting officer may-- close a contract without a final invoice if the amount due is less than $1,000 and less than 10 percent of the contract value; and unilaterally deobligate any unliquidated obligations remaining on the contract; and such contracts may be closed with missing contract documentation if no additional product or service will be received by the Federal Government and there are no outstanding administrative actions. Authority To Write Off Unreconciled Balances for Low-Risk Contracts.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to provide contracting officers, with approval one level above the contracting officer concerned, the authority to write off unreconciled balances on low-risk contracts in cases in which-- all administrative actions are complete, including final payment to the contractor unless exempted under subsection ; and a written notice of the action has been sent to the payment office responsible for the contract. Authority To Grant Exemptions.--The regulations promulgated under this section shall permit the head of contracting activity to grant exemptions to the requirements under this section, with the exemptions included in the contract file. Contracting Officer Defined.--In this section, the term ``contracting officer'' includes procuring and administrative contracting officers. In General.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require heads of executive agencies to mandate that affordability be included as a requirement for major systems, research and development, construction and architect- engineering acquisitions prior to the approval of any acquisition plan exceeding $100,000,000. Affordability Defined.--In this section, the term ``affordability'' refers to conducting an acquisition program at a cost constrained by the maximum resources that an executive agency can allocate for a particular capability. Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require service contracts valued at more than $100,000,000 include provisions to achieve productivity improvements and cost efficiencies. The regulation shall permit the head of contracting activity to grant exceptions to this requirement which shall be included in the contract file. The Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy, in collaboration with the Director of the Defense Procurement and Acquisition Policy, shall establish at least one year from enactment a methodology to track and monitor progress made by executive agencies in achieving measurable acquisition savings. Measurable acquisition savings should include price reductions and cost savings through reduced acquisition costs such as administrative costs. Plan for Reduced Use of Time and Materials Contracts.--Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy, in coordination with the Administrator of General Services and the Secretary of Defense, shall develop a plan for reducing the use of time and materials and labor hour contracts, including for orders under indefinite delivery/ indefinite quantity contracts. Report on Spending on Management Support Service Contracts.-- Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy, in collaboration with the Director of the Defense Procurement and Acquisition Policy, shall submit to Congress a report on reduced spending on management support service contracts. Not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council shall amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to reflect that governmentwide policy is to assist small business concerns by paying them as quickly as possible after invoices and all proper documentation, including acceptance, are received and before normal payment due dates established in the contract."</BILL><SUMMARY>Acquisition Savings Reform Act of 2011 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish governmentwide acquisition savings criteria.Federal Acquisition Regulation Act - Amends the Federal Acquisition Act to direct the Federal acquisition regulatory council to: (1) establish and maintain a Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council (FADC); and (2) enforce a specified interagency acquisition contract or agreement designated by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to leverage the federal government's buying power and save taxpayers money.Directs the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council to amend Federal Acquisition Acquisition Regulation Act to require the heads of executive agencies, to the extent possible, to use online reverse auctions or an equivalent method in the procurement of commercial items above the simplified acquisition threshold whenever doing so would be expected to result in savings to the agencies.Directs the Administrator to issue policy maximizing the participation of small business and other socioeconomic categories in Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles.Directs the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to prescribe regulations requiring chief information officers and chief acquisition officers of Federal agencies to develop and gather data on information technology purchases and service acquisitions by North American industrial classification codes.Directs the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council (FACRB) to develop a plan to achieve $1 billion in measurable savings through federal strategic sourcing vehicles for fiscal years 2013 through 2016. Requires agencies to utilize specified Federal supply schedules, governmentwide acquisition contracts, multi-agency contracts, and other procurement instruments intended for use by multiple agencies, including blanket purchase agreements (Bpas), absent a written justification that the governmentwide contract is not in the best interest of the federal government.Directs the Administrator for Federal procurement policy to amend the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council Act to provide contracting officers with the authority to waive contract closeout audits above the simplified acquisition purchase threshold based on risk assessments.Requires: (1) contractors to submit a final invoice within 60 days of federal government acceptance or relinquish payment unless exempted by the contracting officer; and (2) such contracts may be closed with missing contract documentation if no additional product or service will be received by the federal government and there are no outstanding administrative actions.Requires Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council (FACC) heads to grant contracting officers with approval one level above the contracting officer concerned the authority to write off unreconciled balances for low-risk contracts in cases in which: (1) all administrative actions are complete, including final payment to the contractor unless exempted; and (2) a written notice of the action has been sent to the payment office responsible for the contract.Directs the Administrator of Federal procurement policy to develop a plan for reducing the use of time and materials and labor hour contracts, including for orders under indefinite delivery.Amends the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require the Federal acquisition regulatory council to: (1) require the Administrator of Federal procurement policy to submit to Congress a report on reduced spending on management support service contracts; and (2) require that the Department of Defense, in collaboration with the Director of the National Arms Export Administration (USA) and the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress on spending on such contracts.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.19825053215026855</ALIGNSCORE>

Section 303 of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 (42 U.S.C. 13212) is amended-- by redesignating subsections through as subsections through , respectively; and by inserting after subsection the following: ``Heavy Duty and Dual-Fueled Vehicle Compliance Credits.-- ``In general.--For purposes of meeting the requirements of this section, the Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of General Services, if appropriate, shall permit a Federal fleet to acquire 1 heavy duty alternative fueled vehicle in place of 2 light duty alternative fueled vehicles. ``Additional credits.--For purposes of this section, the Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of General Services, if appropriate, shall permit a Federal fleet to take an additional credit for the purchase and documented use of alternative fuel used in a dual-fueled vehicle, comparable conventionally-fueled motor vehicle, or marine vessel. ``Accounting.-- ``In general.--In allowing a credit for the purchase of a dual-fueled vehicle or alternative fuel, the Secretary may request a Federal agency to provide an accounting of the purchase. ``Guidelines.--The Secretary shall include any request made under subparagraph in the guidelines required under section 308. ``Fuel and vehicle neutrality.--The Secretary shall carry out this subsection in a manner that is, to the maximum extent practicable, neutral with respect to the type of fuel and vehicle used.''. Conversions.--Section 507of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 (42 U.S.C. 13257) is amended-- by striking ``Nothing in'' and inserting the following: ``In general.--Subject to paragraph , nothing in''; and by adding at the end the following: ``Conversion into alternative fueled vehicles.-- ``In general.--A fleet owner shall be permitted to convert an existing fleet vehicle into an alternative fueled vehicle, and purchase the alternative fuel for the converted vehicle, for the purpose of compliance with this title or an amendment made by this title, if the original equipment manufacturer's warranty continues to apply to the vehicle, pursuant to an agreement between the original equipment manufacturer and the person performing the conversion. ``Credits.--A fleet owner shall be allowed a credit for the conversion of an existing fleet vehicle and the purchase of alternative fuel for the vehicle.''. In General.--Section 508of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 (42 U.S.C. 13258) is amended-- by striking ``The Secretary'' and inserting the following: ``Additional alternative fueled vehicles.--The Secretary''; and by adding at the end the following: ``Alternative fuel.--The Secretary shall allocate a credit to a fleet or covered person that acquires a volume of alternative fuel equal to the estimated need for 1 year for any dual-fueled vehicle acquired or converted by the fleet or covered person as required under this title.''. Allocation.--Section 508of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 (42 U.S.C. 13258) is amended-- by striking ``In allocating credits under subsection ,'' and inserting the following: ``Additional alternative fueled vehicles.--In allocating credits under subsection ,''; and by adding at the end the following: ``Dual-fueled vehicles; alternative fuel.--In allocating credits under subsection , the Secretary shall allocate 2 credits to a fleet or covered person for acquiring or converting a dual-fueled vehicle and acquiring a volume of alternative fuel equal to the estimated need for 1 year for any dual-fueled vehicle if the dual-fueled vehicle acquired is in excess of the number that the fleet or covered person is required to acquire or is acquired before the date that the fleet or covered person is required to acquire the number under this title.''. Section 509of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 (42 U.S.C. 13259) is amended-- in paragraph , by inserting before the semicolon at the end the following: ``and exempting replacement fuels from taxes levied on non-replacement fuels''; and in paragraph -- by inserting ``and converters'' after ``suppliers''; and by inserting before the semicolon the following: ``, including the conversion and warranty of motor vehicles into alternative fueled vehicles''."</BILL><SUMMARY>Biodiesel Energy Development Act of 1997 - Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish a minimum federal fleet requirement. Authorizes the use of alternative fuels in diesel vehicles, engines, and marine vessels.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to require the Department of Energy to develop and maintain a policy that:  (1) permits the use of motor vehicles or marine vessels capable of operating on alternative fuel, gasoline, or diesel fuel, or an approved blend of alternative fuel and petroleum-based fuel.Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act (EPCA) to require motor vehicles converted to use alternative fuels at the time of a major vehicle overhaul or rebuild, or vehicles that have been converted to such fuels at such a time as 20% by volume.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to require the Secretary of Energy, in consultation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), to permit a federal fleet to acquire one heavy duty alternative fueled vehicle in place of two light duty alternative fuelled vehicles.Directs the Secretary to: (1) allow a credit for the purchase of a dual-fueled vehicle or alternative fuel vessel; and (2) require such a credit to be credited to consumers who purchase such vehicle or vessel using alternative fuels.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to: (1) extend the Energy Buyback Program through FY2014 to include incentives toward use of alternative fuels; and (2) provide federal financial assistance to states to purchase alternative fuels. Revises provisions regarding alternative fuel bus programs.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to: (1) increase the incremental cost of alternative fuels used in flexible fueled school buses and convert them to alternative fueled vehicles; and (2) require the use of nonroad vehicles and marine vessels to reduce the fuel consumption, emissions, and fuel surcharge for such vehicles.Requires the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to enter into agreements with rail transportation, vehicles used at airports and seaports, and other vehicles used for marine purposes, marine vessels, or other vehicles or engines.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to mandate the conversion of existing fleet vehicles into a dual-fueled alternative fueled vehicle at the time of a major overhaul or rebuild, pursuant to an agreement between the original equipment manufacturer and the person performing the conversion.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to require the Secretary of Energy, to the maximum extent practicable, to be neutral with respect to the type of fuel and vehicle used.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to: (1) require fleets covered by this Act to substitute the acquisition or conversion of one heavy duty alternative fueled vehicle for two light duty vehicle acquisitions to meet the requirements of this Act; and (2) require a fleet owner to purchase alternative fuel for the converted vehicle.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to allow a fleet owner credit for the conversion of an existing fleet vehicle and the purchase of alternative fuel for the vehicle.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to: (1) allocate credits to a fleet or covered person for acquiring or converting a dual-fueled vehicle and acquiring a volume of alternative fuel equal to the estimated need for 1 year.Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to: (1) extend the exemption of replacement fuels from taxes levied on non-replacement fuels to include motor vehicles into alternative fueled vehicles; and (2) require the conversion and warranty of motor vehicles to be issued by the Department of Energy (DOE) as part of the alternative fuels program.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.7602953910827637</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>88</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2001''. Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: ``Specific Practices.--For purposes of subsection , the term `unfair or deceptive practice' includes each of the following: ``Flight delays.--The failure of an air carrier or foreign air carrier to provide a passenger of the carrier with an accurate explanation of the reasons for a flight delay, cancellation, or diversion from a ticketed itinerary. ``Termination of ticket agents.--In the case of a termination, cancellation, nonrenewal, or substantial change in the competitive circumstances of the appointment of a ticket agent by an air carrier or foreign air carrier, the failure of the air carrier or foreign air carrier-- ``to provide the ticket agent with written notice, and a full statement of reasons for the action, on or before the 90th day preceding the action; and ``to provide the ticket agent with at least 60 days to correct any deficiency claimed in the written notice, except in cases of insolvency, an assignment for the benefit of creditors, bankruptcy, or nonpayment of sums due under the appointment.''. Section 41713of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking ``related to a price, route, or service of an air carrier that may provide air transportation under this subpart'' and inserting ``that directly prescribes a price, route, or level of service for air transportation provided by an air carrier under this subpart''. In General.--Subchapter I of chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: ``Sec. 41722. Airline passenger rights ``Right to In-Flight Emergency Medical Care.-- ``In general.--The Secretary of Transportation shall prescribe regulations to establish minimum standards for resuscitation, emergency medical, and first-aid equipment and supplies to be carried on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier in air transportation that is capable of carrying at least 30 passengers. ``Considerations.--In prescribing regulations under paragraph , the Secretary shall consider-- ``the weight and size of the equipment described in paragraph ; ``the need for special training of air carrier personnel to operate the equipment safely and effectively; ``the space limitations of each type of aircraft; ``the effect of the regulations on aircraft operations; ``the practical experience of airlines in carrying and operating similar equipment; and ``other relevant factors. ``Consultation.--Before prescribing regulations under paragraph , the Secretary shall consult with the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service. ``Right To Exit Aircraft.--No air carrier or foreign air carrier operating an aircraft in air transportation shall prevent or hinder (including by failing to assist) any passenger from exiting the aircraft (under the same circumstances as any member of the flight crew is permitted to exit the aircraft) if-- ``the aircraft is parked at an airport terminal gate with access to ramp or other facilities through which passengers are customarily boarded and deplaned; ``the aircraft has remained at the gate more than 1 hour past its scheduled departure time; and ``the captain of the aircraft has not been informed by air traffic control authorities that the aircraft can be cleared for departure within 15 minutes.''. Conforming Amendment.--The analysis for chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: ``41722. Airline passenger rights.''. Requirement for Program.-- In general.--Chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following new section: ``Sec. 44727. Air traveler safety program ``In General.-- ``Written information.--The Secretary of Transportation (in this section referred to as the `Secretary') shall require in regulations, for a period determined by the Secretary, that each air carrier that provides interstate air transportation or foreign air transportation to provide written information upon request, to passengers that purchase passage for interstate or foreign air transportation concerning the following: ``Safety inspection reviews conducted by the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration (in this section referred to as the `Administrator') on the aircraft of that air carrier. ``The safety ranking of that air carrier, as determined by the Administrator in accordance with applicable law. ``The compliance of the members of the crew of the aircraft with any applicable certification requirements under this subtitle. ``Guidelines.--The regulations issued by the Secretary under this subsection shall provide guidelines for air carriers relating to the provision of the information referred to in paragraph . ``Request for information.--An air carrier shall be required to provide to a passenger, on request, any information concerning the safety of aircraft and the competency of persons issued a certificate under this subtitle for the operation of the aircraft that the Secretary, to the extent allowable by law, determines to be appropriate. ``Submission of Performance Review.-- ``In general.--Not later than December 31 of each year, the Secretary shall submit a report to Congress regarding the safety of air carriers that provide interstate or foreign air transportation. The report shall include with respect to the year in which the report is filed-- ``the number of accidents and a description of such accidents of air carriers attributable to each air carrier that provides interstate or foreign air transportation; and ``the names of makers of aircraft that have been involved in an accident. ``Availability of information.--The Secretary shall make the annual report under paragraph available to any person or entity upon request. ``Victims' Rights Program.-- ``In general.--The National Transportation Safety Board shall establish and administer a program for victims and survivors of aircraft accidents in air commerce. Under that program, the National Transportation Safety Board shall ensure that such victims and survivors of an accident receive, to the extent allowable by law, immediate and unrestricted access to information on the accident that is made available from-- ``the air carrier involved in an accident in air commerce; ``the Federal Government; and ``State governments and political subdivisions thereof. ``Classified information.--Nothing in paragraph may be construed to authorize a release of information that is specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy. ``Coordination of Victim Assistance.-- ``In general.--The National Transportation Safety Board, in cooperation with officials of appropriate Federal agencies and the American Red Cross, shall establish a program to ensure the coordination of the disclosure of information under subsection and assistance provided to victims of an accident in air commerce. ``Establishment of toll-free telephone line.-- ``In general.--The National Transportation Safety Board, in cooperation with officials of the appropriate Federal agencies and the American Red Cross, shall establish a toll-free telephone line to facilitate the provision of information under paragraph . ``Action by the national transportation safety board.--The National Transportation Safety Board shall take such action as may be necessary to ensure-- ``the publication of the telephone number of the telephone line established under subparagraph in newspapers of general circulation; and ``the provision of such number on national television news programs. ``Information provided by telephone line.--The telephone line established under paragraph shall provide the following information concerning an accident in air commerce: ``The identifier name and number of the aircraft involved in the accident. ``The names of known victims of the accident. ``The status of the investigation of the accident. ``A list of appropriate Federal agencies and contacts. ``The facilities at which victims of the accident may be identified. ``Civil Penalties.-- ``In general.--Any air carrier that fails to provide information in accordance with this section shall be liable for a civil penalty in an amount not to exceed $100,000 per violation. ``Travel agencies and other persons not covered.-- Paragraph shall not apply to a travel agency or other person that does not provide interstate or foreign air transportation. ``Authorization of Appropriations.--There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as may be necessary to carry out this section.''. Conforming amendment.--The analysis for chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following new item: ``44727. Air traveler safety program.''. Time for Regulations.--The Secretary of Transportation shall issue the regulations required by subsection of section 44727 of title 49, United States Code (as added by subsection ), not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act. Prohibits an airline from terminating an agent if the agent fails to provide such an accurate explanation.Amends the Federal Aviation Act to authorize the Secretary of Transportation to prescribe regulations to establish minimum standards for resuscitation, emergency medical, and first-aid equipment and supplies to be carried on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier in air transportation that is capable of carrying at least 30 passengers.Directs the Secretary to consider the weight and size of the equipment described in subparagraph (A) the need for special training of air carrier personnel to operate the equipment safely and effectively; (B) the effect of the regulations on aircraft operations; (C) the practical experience of airlines in carrying and operating similar equipment; and (D) other relevant factors.Requires each air carrier that provides interstate or foreign air transportation to provide written information upon request to passengers that purchase passage for interstate or Foreign air transportation. Requires such information to be provided to the passengers that they have not been informed by the authorities that the aircraft can be cleared for departure within 15 minutes.Requires an air carrier to provide to a passenger, on request, any information concerning the safety of the aircraft and the competency of the crew, as determined by the Secretary.Requires the Secretary of Transportation to make annual reports available to any person or entity upon request. In General.--Paragraph of section 529of such Code (relating to other definitions and special rules) is amended to read as follows: ``Qualified higher education expenses.-- ``In general.--The term `qualified higher education expenses' means-- ``tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for the enrollment or attendance of a designated beneficiary at an eligible educational institution; and ``expenses for special needs services in the case of a special needs beneficiary which are incurred in connection with such enrollment or attendance. ``Room and board included for students who are at least half-time.-- ``In general.--In the case of an individual who is an eligible student for any academic period, such term shall also include reasonable costs for such period (as determined under the qualified tuition program) incurred by the designated beneficiary for room and board while attending such institution. <ROW>91</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be referred to as the ``Department of the Interior Reform and Savings Act of 1993''. TITLE I--IMPROVE THE FEDERAL HELIUM PROGRAM Section 4 of the Helium Act Amendments of 1960 (74 Stat. 920, 50 U.S.C. 167b) is amended to insert after ``lands acquired, leased, or reserved;'' the following: ``reduce costs and increase operational efficiencies, especially in operations that do not produce revenue; establish and adjust fees charged private industry for storage, transmission, and withdrawal of privately-owned helium from Government storage facilities to compensate fully for all costs incurred;''. Section 6 of the Helium Act Amendments of 1960 (74 Stat. 921, 50 U.S.C. 167d) is amended-- by amending subsection to read: ``The Secretary is authorized to sell helium for Federal, medical, scientific, and commercial uses in such quantities and under such terms and conditions as the Secretary determines. Sales shall be made in quantities and a manner to avoid undue disruption of the usual markets of producers, processors, and consumers of helium and to protect the United States against avoidable loss.''; and by amending subsection to read: ``Sales of helium by the Secretary shall be at prices, as established by the Secretary, that are adequate to cover all costs incurred in carrying out the provisions of this Act. Helium shall be sold at prices comparable to helium sold by private industry. An annual review of price comparability shall be made and adjustments shall be made accordingly.''. The Secretary of the Interior shall prepare and develop a long- term, comprehensive plan to cancel the outstanding debt owed to the Treasury by the Department of the Interior related to the Federal helium program; and improve Federal helium program operations over a multi-year period. The plan should analyze various options to accomplish and above, with emphasis on ways to minimize adverse impacts on Federal employment, Federal helium purchasers, and U.S. private sector helium markets. The plan, with the Secretary's preferred options, shall be presented to the President within 4 months of enactment of this Act. The President may adopt the plan, in whole or in part, and is authorized to cancel the out-standing debt upon a finding that such debt cancellation is in the national interest. TITLE II--IMPROVE MINERALS MANAGEMENT SERVICE ROYALTY COLLECTION COLLECTION.
