The Secretary of the Interior shall, by fiscal year 1995, direct the Minerals Management Service, Royalty Management Program, to develop and implement an automated business information system to provide to its auditors a lease history that includes reference, royalty, production, financial, compliance history, pricing and valuation, and other information; the optimum methods to identify and resolve anomalies and to verify that royalties are paid correctly; a more efficient and cost-effective royalty collection process by instituting new compliance and enforcement measures, including assessments and penalties for erroneous reporting and underreporting; and such other actions as may be necessary to reduce royalty underpayment and increase revenue to the U.S. Treasury by an estimated total of $28 million by fiscal year 1999. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 (Public Law No. 97-451), (30 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.) is amended by adding a new subsection 111as follows: ``penalty assessment for substantial underreporting of royalty'' ``Sec. 111. If there is any underreporting of royalty owned on production from any lease issued or administered by the Secretary for the production of oil, gas, coal, any other mineral, or geothermal steam, from any Federal or Indian lands or the Outer Continental Shelf, for any production month, by any person who is responsible for paying royalty, the Secretary may assess a penalty of 10 percent of the amount of that underreporting. ``If there is a substantial underreporting of royalty owed on production from any lease issued or administered by the Secretary for the production of oil, gas, coal, any other mineral, or geothermal steam, from any Federal or Indian lands or the Outer Continental Shelf, for any production month, by any person who is responsible for paying royalty, the Secretary may access a penalty of 20 percent of the amount of that substantial underreporting. ``For purposes of this section, the term `undereporting' means the difference between the royalty on the value of the production which should have been reported and the royalty on the value of the production which was reported, if the value of the production which should have been reported is greater than the value of the production which was reported. An underreporting constitutes a `substantial underreporting' if such difference exceeds 10 percent of the royalty on the value of the production which should have been reported. ``The Secretary shall not impose the assessment provided in paragraphs or if the person corrects the underreporting before the date the person receives notice from the Secretary that an underreporting may have occurred, or before 90 days after the date of enactment of this section, whichever is later. ``The Secretary shall waive any portion of an assessment provided in paragraphs or attributable to that portion of the underreporting for which the person demonstrates that-- ``the person had written authorization from the Secretary to report royalty on the value of the production on the basis on which it was reported, or ``the person had substantial authority for reporting royalty on the value of the production on the basis on which it was reported, or ``the person previously had notified the Secretary, in such manner as the Secretary may by rule prescribe, of relevant reasons or facts affecting the royalty treatment of specific production which led to the underreporting, or ``the person meets any other exception which the Secretary may, by rule, establish. ``All penalties collected under this subsection shall be deposited to the same accounts in the Treasury or paid to the same recipients in the same manner as the royalty with respect to which such penalty is paid.''. TITLE III--PHASE OUT THE MINERAL INSTITUTE PROGRAM The Secretary of the Interior, beginning in fiscal year 1995, shall take action to phase out the Mining and Mineral Resources Research Institute Act of 1984, Public Law 98-409, as amended (98 Stat. 1536 through 1541 and 102 Stat. 2339 through 2341, 30 U.S.C. 1221 through 1230). There are hereby authorized to be appropriated under the Act the following amounts: fiscal year 1995--$6.5 million; fiscal year 1996--$5 million; fiscal year 1997--$3 million; and fiscal year 1998--$1.5 million. No further appropriations for this Act are authorized after September 30, 1998."</BILL><SUMMARY>Federal Helium Act of 1993 - Amends the National Environmental Policy Act to: (1) make the Federal Government's sale of helium for federal, medical, scientific, and commercial purposes in specified quantities and under specified terms and conditions as the Secretary determines; and (2) establish and adjust fees charged private industry for storage, transmission, and withdrawal of privately-owned helium from government storage facilities to compensate fully for all costs incurred.Directs the Secretary to prepare and develop a long-term, comprehensive plan to cancel the outstanding debt owed to the Treasury by the Department of the Interior related to the federal helium program.Amends the federal oil and gas royalty management Act of 1982 to direct the Secretary of the Interior to develop and implement an automated business information system to provide to auditors a lease history that includes reference, royalty, production, financial, compliance history, pricing and valuation, and other information.Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) underreport the value of oil, gas, coal, or geothermal steam produced from any federal or Indian lands or the outer continental shelf for any production month; and (2) if such underreporting occurs before the date the Secretary receives notice from the Secretary that an underreporting may have occurred, or before 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to take action to phase out the mining and mineral resources research institute program if: (1) the person previously had written authorization from the Secretary to report royalty on the value of the production on the basis on which it was reported; (2) such authorizations were not in effect at the time of the reporting; and (3) such authority is transferred to the same recipients in the same manner as the royalty with respect to which it is paid.Amends the Omnibus Budget Control Act to authorize appropriations under this Act for FY 1995-FY1998.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.2780621647834778</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>92</ROW><BILL>"Future Math and Science Teacher Recruitment.--Title X of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1102 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following new part: ``PART L--FUTURE MATH AND SCIENCE TEACHER RECRUITMENT `` ``Short Title.--This part may be cited as the `Recruit and Reward Future Math and Science Teachers of America Act of 2000'. ``Findings.--Congress finds the following: ``United States high school students rate 16th and 19th, respectively, in science and math out of 21 countries. ``Of United States high school students who take physical science and math courses, 56 percent and 27 percent, respectively, are taught by teachers who did not prepare in that field. ``Teachers' knowledge and skills powerfully influence student learning. ``More than 2,000,000 teachers will need to be hired over the next decade. ``The ability of the United States to place highly qualified math and science teachers specializing in their field of instruction will depend on proactive policies that increase funding for teacher training, recruitment, and induction. `` ``Purpose.--It is the purpose of this part to make grants available, through a pilot program, to eligible institutions described in section 10995C, to enable such institutions to provide 500 scholarship awards to outstanding students enrolled in an accredited teacher training graduate program who are committed to pursuing careers teaching math and science at an urban or rural secondary level classroom. ``Authorization of Appropriations.--There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this part $5,000,000 in each of the fiscal years 2001, 2002, and 2003. `` ``Scholarship Designation.--Funds made available under this part shall be designated as the `National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships'. ``Selection Criteria.--The Secretary of Education may award funds for National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships on a competitive basis to qualifying higher education institutions with graduate programs in teacher training. The Secretary may not provide any individual higher education institution more than $100,000 per academic year for the purpose of the National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships. An institution applying for such scholarships may only be eligible to receive funds if such institution is ranked by the Secretary in the top 25 percent of schools in the State in which the institution is located with the highest percentage of graduates passing the State teacher qualification assessment for new teachers. Notwithstanding the preceding sentence, if there are fewer than 4 such institutions in a State, only the institution with the highest percentage of such graduates shall be eligible to receive funding. ``Priorities.--The Secretary shall give priority to eligible institutions that meet 1 or more of the following criteria: ``Provide a year long internship program in a professional development school. ``Provide mentoring programs for novice teachers in their first 3 years. ``Demonstrate a history of placing graduates in rural and urban schools. ``Demonstrate that there is a high retention rate of teachers that the institution places in teaching positions. `` ``An individual may be eligible for a National Math and Science Teacher Scholarship only if such individual-- ``is a citizen or national of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence; ``is majoring in a physical or life science or mathematics graduate teacher training program; ``is enrolled in a higher education institution that-- ``is ranked by the Secretary in the top 25 percent of schools in the State in which the institution is located with the highest percentage of graduates passing the State teacher qualification assessment for new teachers; or ``if there are are fewer than 4 such institutions in a State, is the institution with the highest percentage of such graduates; and ``is willing to teach math or science in a rural or urban public secondary school for no less than 3 full academic years. `` ``Amount of Award.-- ``In general.--The amount of a scholarship awarded by participating teacher training graduate programs under this part for any academic year shall be $10,000 per student, except that in no case shall the total amount of the scholarship exceed the total cost of attendance. ``Insufficient funds.--In any fiscal year in which the amount appropriated to carry out this part is insufficient to award 500 scholarships, the Secretary shall reduce the number of awards to eligible institutions. ``Assistance Not To Exceed Cost of Attendance.--No individual shall receive an award under this part in any academic year which exceeds the cost of attendance. A scholarship awarded under this part shall not be reduced on the basis of the student's receipt of other forms of Federal student financial assistance. `` ``Agreement.--Recipients of the National Math and Science Teachers Scholarships shall agree to teach in an urban or rural public secondary school for no less than 3 full academic years. ``Repayment for Failure To Fulfill Agreement.--Any recipients of a Scholarship found by the Secretary to be in noncompliance with the agreement entered into under subsection of this section shall be required to repay a pro rata amount of the scholarship awards received, plus interest and, where applicable, reasonable collection fees, on a schedule and at a rate of interest prescribed by the Secretary by regulations. `` ``An individual recipient of a Scholarship under this part shall not be considered in violation of the agreement entered into pursuant to section 10995F during any period in which the recipient-- ``is pursuing a full-time course of study in math and science at an accredited institution; ``is serving, not in excess of 3 years, as a member of the armed services of the United States; ``is temporarily disabled for a period of time not to exceed 3 years as established by sworn affidavit of a qualified physician; ``is seeking and unable to find full-time employment for a single period not to exceed 12 months; ``is seeking and unable to find full-time employment as a math and science teacher in a public or private nonprofit elementary or secondary school or education program for a single period not to exceed 27 months; ``satisfies the provision of additional repayment exceptions that may be prescribed by the Secretary in regulations issued pursuant to this section; or ``is permanently totally disabled, as established by sworn affidavit of a qualified physician. `` ``Three years after the date on which funds are first made available to carry out this part, the Secretary of Education shall submit a report to Congress evaluating the success of the National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships pilot program in recruiting math and science teachers to teach in America's public secondary schools.''."</BILL><SUMMARY>Future Math and Science Teacher Recruitment Act of 2000 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to recruit and reward future math and science teachers.National Math and Science Teacher Scholarship Program Act of 2001 - Amends the Education Act to direct the Secretary of Education to establish a pilot program to provide $5,000,000 for the purpose of the national math and science teacher scholarships.National Math and Science Teacher Scholarship Program (NUTS) eligibility. Requires an individual to: (1) enroll in a higher education institution that:   is ranked in the top 25% of schools in the state in which the institution is located with the highest percentage of graduates passing the State Teacher qualification assessment; (2) is a citizen or national lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence; and (3) is willing to teach in a rural or urban public secondary school for no less than three full academic years.Requires the Secretary of Education to reduce the award of a National Math and Science Teachers Scholarship award to $10,000 per student.Allows recipients of a scholarship awarded under this Act to repay pro rata amounts of scholarship awards received plus interest and reasonable collection fees at a rate of interest.Requires the Secretary to report to Congress on the success of the National Math and Science Teacher Scholarship pilot program in recruiting math and science teachers to teach in American public secondary schools.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.28863808512687683</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>93</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Irrigation Subsidy Reduction Act of 1996''. Congress finds that-- the Federal reclamation program has been in existence for over 90 years, with an estimated taxpayer investment of over $70,000,000,000; the program has had and continues to have an enormous effect on the water resources and aquatic environments of the western States; irrigation water made available from Federal water projects in the West is a very valuable resource for which there are increasing and competing demands; the justification for providing water at less than full cost was to benefit and promote the development of small family farms and exclude large corporate farms, but this purpose has been frustrated over the years due to inadequate implementation of subsidy and acreage limits; below-cost water prices tend to encourage excessive use of scarce water supplies in the arid regions of the West, and reasonable price increases to the wealthiest western farmers would provide an economic incentive for greater water conservation; the Federal Government has increasingly applied eligibility tests based on income for Federal entitlement and subsidy programs, measures that are consistent with the historic approach of the reclamation program's acreage limitations that seek to limit water subsidies to smaller farms; and including a means test based on gross income in the reclamation program will increase the effectiveness of carrying out the family farm goals of the Federal reclamation laws. Definitions.--Section 202 of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390bb) is amended-- by redesignating paragraphs , , , , and as paragraphs , , , , and , respectively; in paragraph by striking ``owned or operated under a lease which'' and inserting ``owned, leased, or operated by an individual or legal entity and which''; by inserting after paragraph the following: ``Legal entity.--The term `legal entity' includes a corporation, association, partnership, trust, joint tenancy, or tenancy in common, or any other entity that owns, leases, or operates a farm operation for the benefit of more than 1 individual under any form of agreement or arrangement. ``Operator.-- ``In general.--The term `operator'-- ``means an individual or legal entity that operates a single farm operation on a parcel (or parcels) of land that is owned or leased by another person (or persons) under any form of agreement or arrangement (or agreements or arrangements); and ``if the individual or legal entity-- ``is an employee of an individual or legal entity, includes the individual or legal entity; or ``is a legal entity that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another legal entity, includes each such other legal entity. ``Operation of a farm operation.--For the purposes of subparagraph , an individual or legal entity shall be considered to operate a farm operation if the individual or legal entity is the person that performs the greatest proportion of the decisionmaking for and supervision of the agricultural enterprise on land served with irrigation water.''; and by adding at the end the following: ``Single farm operation.-- ``In general.--The term `single farm operation' means the total acreage of land served with irrigation water for which an individual or legal entity is the operator. ``Rules for determining whether separate parcels are operated as a single farm operation.-- ``Equipment- and labor-sharing activities.--The conduct of equipment- and labor-sharing activities on separate parcels of land by separate individuals or legal entities shall not by itself serve as a basis for concluding that the farming operations of the individuals or legal entities constitute a single farm operation. ``Performance of certain services.-- The performance by an individual or legal entity of an agricultural chemical application, pruning, or harvesting for a farm operation on a parcel of land shall not by itself serve as a basis for concluding that the farm operation on that parcel of land is part of a single farm operation operated by the individual or entity on other parcels of land.''. Identification of Owners, Lessees, and Operators and of Single Farm Operations.--The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 39aa et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 201 the following: `` SINGLE FARM OPERATIONS. ``In General.--Subject to subsection , for each parcel of land to which irrigation water is delivered or proposed to be delivered, the Secretary shall identify a single individual or legal entity as the owner, lessee, or operator. ``Shared Decisionmaking and Supervision.--If the Secretary determines that no single individual or legal entity is the owner, lessee, or other individual that performs the greatest proportion of decisionmaking for and supervision of the agricultural enterprise on a parcel of land-- ``all individuals and legal entities that own, lease, or perform a proportion of decisionmaking and supervision that is equal as among themselves but greater than the proportion performed by any other individual or legal entity shall be considered jointly to be the owner, lessee, or operator; and ``all parcels of land of which any such individual or legal entity is the owner, lessee, or operator shall be considered to be part of the single farm operation of the owner, lessee, or operator identified under subsection . Pricing.--Section 205 of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390ee) is amended by adding at the end the following: ``Single Farm Operations Generating More Than $500,000 in Gross Farm Income.-- ``In general.--Notwithstanding subsections , , and , in the case of-- ``a qualified recipient that reports gross farm income from a single farm operation in excess of $500,000 for a taxable year; or ``a limited recipient that received irrigation water on or before October 1, 1981, and that reports gross farm income from a single farm operation in excess of $500,000 for a taxable year; irrigation water may be delivered to the single farm operation of the qualified recipient or limited recipient at less than full cost to a number of acres that does not exceed the number of acres determined under paragraph . ``Maximum number of acres to which irrigation water may be delivered at less than full cost.--The number of acres determined under this subparagraph is the number equal to the number of acres of the single farm operation multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is $500,000 and the denominator of which is the amount of gross farm income reported by the qualified recipient or limited recipient in the most recent taxable year. ``Inflation adjustment.-- ``In general.--The $500,000 amount under paragraphs and for any taxable year beginning in a calendar year after 1997 shall be equal to the product of-- ``$500,000, multiplied by ``the inflation adjustment factor for the taxable year. ``Inflation adjustment factor.--The term `inflation adjustment factor' means, with respect to any calendar year, a fraction the numerator of which is the GDP implicit price deflator for the preceding calendar year and the denominator of which is the GDP implicit price deflator for 1996. Not later than April 1 of any calendar year, the Secretary shall publish the inflation adjustment factor for the preceding calendar year. ``GDP implicit price deflator.--For purposes of subparagraph , the term `GDP implicit price deflator' means the first revision of the implicit price deflator for the gross domestic product as computed and published by the Secretary of Commerce. ``Rounding.--If any increase determined under subparagraph is not a multiple of $100, the increase shall be rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100.''. Certification of Compliance.--Section 206 of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390ff) is amended to read as follows: `` ``In General.--As a condition to the receipt of irrigation water for land in a district that has a contract described in section 203, each owner, lessee, or operator in the district shall furnish the district, in a form prescribed by the Secretary, a certificate that the owner, lessee, or operator is in compliance with this title, including a statement of the number of acres owned, leased, or operated, the terms of any lease or agreement pertaining to the operation of a farm operation, and, in the case of a lessee or operator, a certification that the rent or other fees paid reflect the reasonable value of the irrigation water to the productivity of the land. ``Documentation.--The Secretary may require a lessee or operator to submit for the Secretary's examination-- ``a complete copy of any lease or other agreement executed by each of the parties to the lease or other agreement; and ``a copy of the return of income tax imposed by chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for any taxable year in which the single farm operation of the lessee or operator received irrigation water at less than full cost.''. Trusts.--Section 214 of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390nn) is repealed. Administrative Provisions.-- Penalties.--Section 224of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390ww) is amended-- by striking ``The Secretary'' and inserting the following: ``Regulations; Data Collection; Penalties.-- ``Regulations; data collection.--The Secretary''; and by adding at the end the following: ``Penalties.--Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Secretary shall establish appropriate and effective penalties for failure to comply with any provision of this Act or any regulation issued under this Act.''. Interest.--Section 224of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390ww) is amended by striking the last sentence and inserting the following: ``The interest rate applicable to underpayments shall be equal to the rate applicable to expenditures under section 202.''. Reporting.--Section 228 of the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390zz) is amended by inserting ``operator or'' before ``contracting entity'' each place it appears. Memorandum of Understanding.--The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390aa et seq.) is amended-- by redesignating sections 229 and 230 as sections 230 and 231; and by inserting after section 228 the following: `` ``The Secretary, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Secretary of Agriculture shall enter into a memorandum of understanding or other appropriate instrument to permit the Secretary, notwithstanding section 6103 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, to have access to and use of available information collected or maintained by the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Agriculture that would aid enforcement of the ownership and pricing limitations of Federal reclamation law.''."</BILL><SUMMARY>Irrigation Solicitation Submergence Reduction Act of 1996 - Amends the Environmental Protection Agency (EDA) Act to require the Federal government to provide water at no more than full cost to small family farms and exclude large corporate farms. The Act directs the Department of the Interior to administer the federal reclamation program at a cost to taxpayers.Amends the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 to revise the definition of a legal entity as one that owns, leases, or operates a farm operation for the benefit of more than 1 individual under any form of agreement or arrangement.Single Farm Organization Act - Amends the Farm Act to require an individual or legal entity to operate a single farm operation if: (1) is an employee of an entity; or (2) is a legal entity that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another legal entity, including each such other legal entity.Amends the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 to: (1) establish a single farm operation on a parcel of land for which an individual or legal entity is the operator; and (2) establish rules for the performance of certain agricultural chemical application, pruning, or harvesting for a farm operation.Requires the Agriculture Department to identify a single entity as the owner, lessee, or operator of a single farm operation.Amends the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 to allow a qualified recipient or limited recipient to report gross farm income up to $500,000 for a taxable year.Directs the Secretary to publish the inflation adjustment factor for 1996.Directs each owner, lessee, or operator to furnish the district with a certificate certifying that the owner is in compliance with this title.Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) require a lessee or operator to submit for the Secretary's examination a complete copy of any lease executed by each of the parties to the lease or other agreement; and (2) a copy of the return of income tax for any taxable year in which the single farm operation of the lesseeor received irrigation water at less than full cost.Requires the Secretary to establish appropriate and effective penalties for failure to comply with any provision of this Act or any regulation issued under it.Directs the Secretary to enter into a memorandum of understanding or other appropriate instrument to permit the Secretary, notwithstanding the Internal Revenue Code, to have access to and use of available information collected or maintained by the Department of the Treasury and the Agriculture that would aid enforcement of the ownership and pricing limitations of federal reclamation law.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.06216457486152649</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>94</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Hospital Price Disclosure Act of 2005''. DATA. Requirement.-- Hospitals.--Subsection of section 1866 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395cc) is amended-- in subparagraph , by striking ``and'' at the end; in subparagraph , by striking the period at the end and inserting ``, and''; and by inserting after subparagraph the following new subparagraph: ``in the case of a hospital, to report to the Secretary data in accordance with subsection and to post notice regarding such data in accordance with subsection .''. Ambulatory surgical centers.--Section 1832of such Act (42 U.S.C. 1395k) is amended by inserting after ``other standards'' the following: ``, including the reporting to the Secretary of data in accordance with section 1866and the posting of notice regarding such data in accordance with section 1866''. Data Reporting by Hospitals and Ambulatory Surgical Centers for Certain Inpatient and Outpatient Procedures and Inpatient Drugs.-- Section 1866 of such Act (42 U.S.C. 1395cc) is further amended by adding at the end the following new subsection: ``Data Reporting by Hospitals and Ambulatory Surgical Centers and Public Posting.-- ``Quarterly reporting requirement.--Not later than 45 days after the end of each calendar quarter (beginning more than one year after the date of the enactment of this subsection), a hospital shall report to the Secretary, for each procedure or drug selected under paragraph , and an ambulatory surgical center shall report to the Secretary, for each procedure selected under paragraph , the following data: ``The frequency with which the hospital performed the procedure, or administered the drug in an inpatient setting, or the center performed the procedure during such quarter. ``If the procedure was performed or the drug was so administered during such quarter, the average and the median of the price charged by the hospital or center for such procedure or drug during such quarter. ``Public availability of data.-- ``Public posting of data.--The Secretary shall promptly post, on the official public Internet site of the Department of Health and Human Services, the data reported under paragraph . Such data shall be set forth in a manner that promotes price comparison among hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers. ``Notice of availability.--A hospital and ambulatory surgical center shall prominently post at each admission site of the hospital or center a notice of the availability of the data reported under paragraph on the official public Internet site under subparagraph . ``Selection of procedures and drugs.-- ``Initial selection.--Based on national data, the Secretary shall select the following: ``The 25 most frequently performed hospital inpatient procedures. ``The 25 most frequently performed hospital outpatient procedures. ``The 50 most frequently administered drugs in a hospital inpatient setting. ``Updating selection.--The Secretary shall periodically update the procedures and drugs selected under subparagraph . ``Civil money penalty.--The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of not more than $10,000 for each knowing violation of the provisions of paragraph or by a hospital or ambulatory surgical center. A civil money penalty under this paragraph shall be imposed and collected in the same manner as a civil money penalty under subsection of section 1128A is imposed and collected under that section. ``Administrative provisions.-- ``Classification of procedures.--For purposes of this subsection, the Secretary shall establish rules for the classification of different procedures and for the assignment of items and services to those procedures. ``Computation of average and median prices.-- For purposes of paragraph , the computation of an average and median price for a procedure or drug shall be in accordance with a methodology prescribed by the Secretary. Such methodology may provide for reporting by the hospital or ambulatory surgical center of unit prices for specific items and services included in a procedure, including appropriate per diem prices, and a method of converting such unit prices for a procedure to an average and median price for such procedure. ``Form of report and notice.--The Secretary shall specify the electronic form and manner by which a hospital or ambulatory surgical center shall report data under paragraph and the form for posting of notices under paragraph . ``Non-preemption of state laws.--Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as preempting or otherwise affecting any provision of State law relating to the disclosure of price or other information for a hospital or ambulatory surgical center. ``Drug defined.--For purposes of this subsection, the term `drug' includes a biological and a non-prescription drug, such as an ointment. ''."</BILL><SUMMARY>Hospital Price Disclosure Act of 2005 - Amends the Social Security Act to require public disclosure of hospital and ambulatory surgical center data.Amends the Act to require: (1) data reporting by hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers for inpatient and outpatient procedures and drugs; and (2) public availability of data.Requires: (1) the Secretary to: (2) collect and analyze the data; and (3) publish it in a manner that promotes price comparison among hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers.Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish rules for the classification of procedures and for the assignment of items and services to such procedures.Requires the Secretary to specify the electronic form and manner by which a hospital or ambulatory surgical center shall report data and the form for posting of notices under this Act.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.8707880973815918</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>95</ROW><BILL>"Short Title.--This Act may be cited as the ``Preserving Equitable Access to Community-based Home Health Act of 2009''. Purpose.--It is the purpose of this Act to preserve access to home health services for all Americans, regardless of their ability to pay or their severity of illness. The Congress finds the following: The Medicare home health benefit is vulnerable to agency selection of the most profitable beneficiaries and avoidance of the most complex and costly beneficiaries. Such ``cherry picking'' by some home health agencies compromises access to care for the most complex, highest risk beneficiaries. The Government Accountability Office has reported that hospital discharge planners have difficulty placing more than 10 percent of eligible patients in home health due to their extensive care needs. Proposals to reduce Medicare payments to home health agencies (in response to large aggregate margins across all home health agencies) may undermine the financial viability of mission-driven and non-profit home health agencies, which often have low to negative margins, while allowing high-margin agencies to remain in operation. In General.--There shall be established a fund (to be known as the ``PEACH fund'') from which home health agencies meeting specified criteria shall be paid supplemental amounts in addition to their statutory payment amounts under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Is this to be a trust fund? Where is this fund to be established? Who adminsters it? What are the sources of funding that goes into the fund? What are the allowed uses of such funding? Peach Program.--Title XVIII of the Social Security Act is amended by inserting after section 1895 the following new section: ``supplemental payments for peach agencies ``Sec. 1895A. Designation.-- ``In general.--The Secretary shall designate as a `PEACH agency' any home health agency that meets the criteria under paragraph . ``Criteria.--The Secretary may not designate a home health agency as a PEACH agency unless the home health agency meets the following criteria: ``The home health agency is certified for participation under this title. ``The home health agency offers-- ``the complete range of home health services as defined under section 1861of this title; ``the complete range of home health services on a 24 hours per day, 7 days per week on-call basis; and ``its services to all eligible beneficiaries or enrollees under this title and/or title XIX, and uninsured individuals up to its service capacity, regardless of their ability to pay or the complexity or intensity of care they require. ``The home health agency provides charity care in an amount greater than or equal to 1 percent of its total revenue. ``The home health agency agrees that the Secretary may, by statistical or other means, verify on an annual basis that the agency meets the criteria defined in this paragraph, and that the agency will be subject to disqualification from the PEACH program if such criteria are not met. ``Supplemental Payments.-- ``In general.--Subject to the availability of funds under subsection , the Secretary shall make supplemental payments to PEACH agencies based on information submitted by the agency on an additional schedule in the Medicare cost report. ``Cost reporting.--The Secretary shall implement an additional schedule, as a component of the cost reporting process, on which home health agencies may report information the Secretary deems necessary for designation and payment as a PEACH agency. ``Amount and timing for first year as peach agency.-- ``The supplemental payment made to a home health agency for the first year in which such agency is designated a PEACH agency under this section shall be equal to its shortfall in that year, defined as the sum of-- ``the aggregate reasonable cost of home health services delivered under parts A and B of this title by the PEACH agency for such year, less the aggregate payments received by the PEACH agency pursuant to section 1895; ``the aggregate actual costs of home health and home and community based services delivered by the agency under sections 1905, 1905, and 1915through of title XIX for such year, less the aggregate payments received by the PEACH agency for such services under that title; and ``the aggregate cost of uncompensated home health services delivered by the PEACH agency for such year. ``The supplemental payment under subparagraph shall be paid within 90 days of receipt of the annual cost report by the Secretary. ``Amount and timing for subsequent years.--For each year after the first year in which a home health agency is designated a PEACH agency, a PEACH agency shall receive interim supplemental payments based on-- ``the intervals at which the agency submits cost reports; and ``the estimated shortfall, as defined in subparagraph , for the year or interval in question. ``Funding.--Supplemental payments under this section shall be-- ``paid from the PEACH fund, which shall be capped at $500,000,000 annually and shall be administered by the Secretary; and ``paid to PEACH agencies-- ``pursuant to subsection ; or ``if the PEACH fund is insufficient to cover all the supplemental payments that should be paid under subsection , in proportion to each agency's shortfall relative to the aggregate shortfall of all PEACH agencies for the year in question. In any year in which the Secretary determines that the PEACH fund will not cover the aggregate estimated shortfall of all PEACH agencies, the Secretary shall make a preliminary supplemental payment to each PEACH agency within 90 days of receipt of its annual cost report and, if funds remain, an additional supplemental payment after all PEACH agency cost reports have been received. ``Definitions.--For purposes of this section-- ``the term `charity care' means home health services that are provided to an individual who is-- ``not eligible for payment under this title, under title XIX, or by any other third-party payer; and ``unable to pay any portion of the full cost of care, including any amount subsidized or otherwise discounted due to an individual's inability to pay; and ``the term `uncompensated care' means home health services provided to an individual by a home health agency with the knowledge that the individual will be financially unable to pay for the services.''. Conforming Amendment.--Section 1895of the Social Security Act is amended by inserting before the period at the end the following: ``and the provisions of section 1895A''. The Secretary shall issue such regulations as are necessary and appropriate for the implementation of the provisions of this Act. There is authorized for appropriation $500,000,000 for each fiscal year beginning with fiscal year 2010 for purposes of carrying out the purposes of this Act. Is there anything this funds other than the PEACH fund? Should this go into the provision creating that fund?"</BILL><SUMMARY>Preserving Access to Home Health Act of 2009 - Directs the Congress to consider reducing medicare home health benefit payments to: (1) the Medicare Home Health Benefit (Medicare) beneficiaries vulnerable to agency selection of the most profitable beneficiaries and to avoidance of such beneficiaries; and (2) Medicare Advantage (Medicaid) beneficiaries are disadvantaged in choosing the most complex beneficiaries.Prohibits such funds from being used to pay for the home health agency's supplemental payments. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to designate as a peach agency any agency that meets specified criteria.Requires the HHS secretary to make supplemental payments to:  (1) agencies that meet specified criteria; and (2) the agency that provides charity care in an amount equal to 1 percent of its total revenue.Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to designate a home health agency (HHS) as a peach agency based on its aggregate reasonable cost of home health services and services delivered.Provides interim supplemental payments based on: (1) the intervals at which the agency submits cost reports; and (2) the estimated shortfall for the year or interval in question.Provides that the peach fund shall make a preliminary supplemental payment to each agency within 90 days of receipt of its annual cost report and an additional supplemental payment after all peach agency cost reports have been received.Amends the Social Security Act to authorize appropriations for FY2010 through FY2010 for the peach fund, the State Department's portion of which is earmarked for the Peach Fund, to be used for the implementation of specified social security programs.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.48444440960884094</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>96</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Long Island Sound Stewardship Act of 2004''. Findings.--Congress finds that-- Long Island Sound is a national treasure of great cultural, environmental, and ecological importance; 8,000,000 people live within the Long Island Sound watershed and 28,000,000 people (approximately 10 percent of the population of the United States) live within 50 miles of Long Island Sound; activities that depend on the environmental health of Long Island Sound contribute more than $5,000,000,000 each year to the regional economy; the portion of the shoreline of Long Island Sound that is accessible to the general public (estimated at less than 20 percent of the total shoreline) is not adequate to serve the needs of the people living in the area; existing shoreline facilities are in many cases overburdened and underfunded; large parcels of open space already in public ownership are strained by the effort to balance the demand for recreation with the needs of sensitive natural resources; approximately \1/3\ of the tidal marshes of Long Island Sound have been filled, and much of the remaining marshes have been ditched, dyked, or impounded, reducing the ecological value of the marshes; and many of the remaining exemplary natural landscape is vulnerable to further development. Purpose.--The purpose of this Act is to establish the Long Island Sound Stewardship System to preserve areas of critical importance because of the open space, public access, and ecological value of the areas. In this Act: Committee.--The term ``Committee'' means the Long Island Sound Stewardship Coordinating Committee established by section 5. Region.--The term ``Region'' means the Long Island Sound Stewardship System Region established by section 4. States.--The term ``States'' means the States of Connecticut and New York. Establishment.--There is established in the States the Long Island Sound Stewardship System Region. Boundaries.--The Region shall encompass the immediate coastal upland and underwater areas along Long Island Sound, including those portions of the Sound with coastally influenced vegetation, as described on the map entitled the ``Long Island Sound Stewardship Region'' and dated April 21, 2004. Establishment.--There is established a committee to be known as the ``Long Island Sound Stewardship Coordinating Committee''. Chairperson.--The Chairperson of the Committee shall be the Director of the Long Island Sound Office of the Environmental Protection Agency, or designee. Membership.-- Composition.-- In general.--The chairperson shall appoint the members of the Committee in accordance with this subsection and section 320of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1330). Representation.--The Committee shall-- include equal representation of the interests of the States; and represent-- Federal, State, and local government interests; the interests of nongovernmental organizations; academic interests; and private interests. Date of appointments.--The appointment of a member of the Committee shall be made not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act. Term; Vacancies.-- Term.--A member shall be appointed for the life of the Committee. Vacancies.--A vacancy on the Committee-- shall not affect the powers of the Committee; and shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment was made. Initial Meeting.--Not later than 30 days after the date on which all members of the Committee have been appointed, the Committee shall hold the initial meeting of the Committee. Meetings.--The Committee shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, but not less than 4 times each year. Quorum.--A majority of the members of the Committee shall constitute a quorum, but a lesser number of members may hold hearings. The Committee shall-- consistent with the guidelines described in section 9-- establish specific criteria for the evaluation of applications for stewardship site designations; and evaluate and award or deny stewardship designation to applicants for that designation; consistent with the guidelines described in section 9-- evaluate applications from government or nonprofit organizations qualified to hold conservation easements for funds to purchase land or development rights for stewardship sites; and award funds to qualified applicants; not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, develop and publish a management plan that-- assesses the current resources of and threats to Long Island Sound; assesses the role of the Long Island Sound Stewardship System in protecting Long Island Sound; establishes-- guidelines, schedules, and due dates for applying for designation as a stewardship site; and specific criteria to be used in evaluating stewardship site applications; includes information about any grants that are available for the purchase of land or property rights to protect stewardship sites; shall be made available to the public on the Internet and in hardcopy form; and shall be updated at least every other year, with information on applications for stewardship site designation and funding published more frequently; and concurrent with the first management plan, publish a list of sites that the Committee considers most appropriate for designation as stewardship sites. Hearings.--The Committee may hold such hearings, meet and act at such times and places, take such testimony, and receive such evidence as the Committee considers advisable to carry out this Act. Information From Federal Agencies.-- In general.--The Committee may secure directly from a Federal agency such information as the Committee considers necessary to carry out this Act. Provision of information.--On request of the Chairperson of the Committee, the head of the agency shall provide the information to the Committee. Postal Services.--The Committee may use the United States mails in the same manner and under the same conditions as other agencies of the Federal Government. Gifts.--The Committee may accept, use, and dispose of gifts or donations of services or property. Compensation of Members.-- Non-federal employees.--A member of the Committee who is not an officer or employee of the Federal Government shall be compensated at a rate equal to the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for level IV of the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code, for each day (including travel time) during which the member is engaged in the performance of the duties of the Committee. Federal employees.--A member of the Committee who is an officer or employee of the Federal Government shall serve without compensation in addition to the compensation received for the services of the member as an officer or employee of the Federal Government. Travel Expenses.--A member of the Committee shall be allowed travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, at rates authorized for an employee of an agency under subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, while away from the home or regular place of business of the member in the performance of the duties of the Committee. Staff.-- In general.--The Chairperson of the Committee may, without regard to the civil service laws (including regulations), appoint and terminate an executive director and such other additional personnel as are necessary to enable the Committee to perform the duties of the Committee. Confirmation of executive director.--The employment of an executive director shall be subject to confirmation by the Committee. Compensation.-- In general.--Except as provided in subparagraph , the Chairperson of the Committee may fix the compensation of the executive director and other personnel without regard to the provisions of chapter 51 and subchapter III of chapter 53 of title 5, United States Code, relating to classification of positions and General Schedule pay rates. Maximum rate of pay.--The rate of pay for the executive director and other personnel shall not exceed the rate payable for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of title 5, United States Code. Detail of Federal Government Employees.-- In general.--An employee of the Federal Government may be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. Civil service status.--The detail of the employee shall be without interruption or loss of civil service status or privilege. Procurement of Temporary and Intermittent Services.--The Chairperson of the Committee may procure temporary and intermittent services in accordance with section 3109of title 5, United States Code, at rates for individuals that do not exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of that title. Definition of Qualifying Land.--In this section, the term ``qualifying land'' means land-- that is in the Region; and that is-- Federal, State, local, or tribal land; land owned by a nonprofit organization; or privately owned land. Application for Designation.--Owners or other parties in control of qualifying land may apply to the Committee to have the qualifying land designated as a Long Island Sound stewardship site. General Guidelines for Stewardship Site Designation.-- In general.--The Committee shall choose land to be designated as a stewardship site based on-- the contribution of the land to open space on and public access to Long Island Sound; and the ecological value of the land. Criteria.--In considering land described in applications submitted under subsection , the Committee shall consider-- land cover; size; adjacency and connectivity to existing parks and open spaces; water quality; current or prospective recreational use; visitor demand; scenic quality; cultural resources; erosion and flood hazard prevention; environmental justice; fish and wildlife productivity; biodiversity; scientific value; water quality protection; habitat restoration characteristics; connectivity to other habitats that are vital to sustaining healthy living resources in the Long Island Sound watershed; risk of development; and other criteria developed by the Committee under section 6. General Guidelines for Awarding Funds.-- In general.--The Committee shall award funds to qualified applicants to help to secure and improve the open space, public access, or ecological values of stewardship sites, through-- purchase of the property of the site; purchase of relevant property rights of the site; or entering into any other binding legal arrangement that ensures that the values of the site are preserved. Equitable distribution of funds.--The Committee shall exert due diligence to distribute funds equitably between the States. In General.--There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out this Act $40,000,000 for each fiscal year, to be allocated from the national estuary program under section 320 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1330). Allocation of Funds.--For each fiscal year-- not more than 15 percent of funds made available under subsection shall be used to improve the facilities of stewardship sites; and at least 85 percent of funds made available under subsection shall be used to secure the values of stewardship sites. Federal Share.--The Federal share of the cost of an activity carried out using any assistance or grant under this Act shall not exceed 75 percent of the total cost of the activity."</BILL><SUMMARY>Long Island Sound Stewardhip Act of 2004 - (Sec. 2) Establishes the Long Island Fishery Conservation Area of Washington, D.C. (D.C.) as a national treasure.Long Island Sound Stewardhip System Act of 2004 - Establishes in Connecticut and New York the long island Sound Stewardship System Region, which includes the following areas:  (1) the immediate coastal upland and underwater areas along Long island Sound, including those with coastally influenced vegetation, as described on the map entitled the "Long Island Sound Preserve System Region" and dated april 21, 2004.Long Island Sound Stewardship Coordinating Committee - Establishes a committee to be named after Long Island's Long Island Environmental Protection Agency (LEPEO) director, the Director of the Long Island Office of the Environmental Protection agency, or designee.Requires the Committee to: (1) establish specific criteria for the evaluation of applications for designated sites; and (2) evaluate and award or deny designation to applicants for that designation.Requires the Committee to:  (1) evaluate applications for designation as a Steward Site; (2) award funds to qualified applicants; and (3) publish a management plan that:  assesses the current resources of and threats to Long Island Sound and assesses a role of the Long Island sound Steward System in protecting long island sound.Directs the Committee to: (1) hold such hearings, meet and act at such times and places, take such testimony, and receive such evidence as the committee considers advisable to carry out this Act; and (2) transmit directly to the Committee any information that the committee finds pertinent to the purpose of this Act. Requires the committee to secure directly from a federal agency such information as the agency considers necessary to carryout this Act, and to provide such information to the Secretary of the Treasury on specified time and place.Requires the chairperson of the Committee to appoint and terminate an executive director and other additional personnel without regard to the civil service laws.Authorizes the Administrator of the Federal Government to procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of basic pay.Long Island Sound Stewardship Site Designation Act - Designates land owned by a nonprofit organization or private landowner to be designated as a stewardship site based on: (1) the contribution of the land to open space on and public access to Long island sound; and (2) the ecological value of the lands.Directs the National Estuary Program to award funds to qualified applicants to help to improve the open space, public access, or ecological values of stewardship sites, through: (1) purchase of the property of the site; (2) entering into any other binding legal arrangement that ensures that such values are preserved.Requires the Federal share of the cost of an activity using assistance or grant funds to improve the facilities of stewardship sites.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.2534336745738983</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>97</ROW><BILL>"Short Title.--This Act may be cited as the ``Strengthening the Transition and Reintegration Of the National Guard and Reserves Act'' or the ``STRONGR Act''. Table of Contents.--The table of contents for this Act is as follows: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents. Sec. 2. Extension of transitional health care coverage to one year for members of reserve components for mental health care. Sec. 3. Increase in amount of basic educational assistance for members of the Selected Reserve and members of reserve components supporting contingency operations. Sec. 4. Nonreduction in pay while Federal employee is serving on active duty in a reserve component of the uniformed services. Sec. 5. Assistance for State and local governments that continue to pay employees who serve on active duty in a reserve component of the uniformed services. Sec. 6. Active-duty reserve component employee credit added to general business credit. MEMBERS OF RESERVE COMPONENTS FOR MENTAL HEALTH CARE. Section 1145of title 10, United States Code, is amended in paragraph -- by inserting ``'' after ``''; and by adding at the end the following new subparagraph: ``In addition to the period described in subparagraph , transitional health care shall be available for an additional 180 days, for mental health care only, to a member of a reserve component described in paragraph . The additional 180 days shall begin at the end of the period described in subparagraph .''. OF THE SELECTED RESERVE AND MEMBERS OF RESERVE COMPONENTS SUPPORTING CONTINGENCY OPERATIONS. Members of Selected Reserve.-- Increase in amount of assistance.--Section 16131of title 10, United States Code, is amended-- in paragraph , by striking ``at the following rates'' and all that follows through the end and inserting ``at the rate provided under paragraph .''; and in paragraph , by striking all and inserting the following: ``Educational assistance provided under this chapter shall be paid at a rate equal the applicable percentage under subparagraph of the rate provided under section 3015of title 38 for an approved program of education pursued on a full-time basis. ``The applicable percentage under this subparagraph is-- ``50 percent for each month in which the individual pursues an approved program of education on a full time basis; ``37.5 percent for each month in which the individual pursues an approved program of education on a three-quarter- time basis; ``25 percent for each month in which the individual pursues an approved program of education on a half-time basis; and ``an appropriately reduced percent, as determined under regulations which the Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall prescribe, for each month in which the individual pursues an approved program of education on less than a half-time basis, except that no payment may be made to an individual for a month in which the individual pursues such a program on less than a half-time basis if tuition assistance is otherwise available to the individual for such pursuit from the military department concerned.''. Effective date.--The amendments made by paragraph shall apply with respect to an educational assistance allowance under section 16131of such title paid for months beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Reserve Components Supporting Contingency Operations.-- Increase in amount.--Section 16162of title 10, United States Code, is amended-- in subparagraph by striking ``40 percent'' and inserting ``60 percent''; and in subparagraph by striking ``60 percent'' and inserting ``70 percent''. Effective date.--The amendments made by paragraph shall apply with respect to an educational assistance allowance under section 16162of such title paid for months beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. DUTY IN A RESERVE COMPONENT OF THE UNIFORMED SERVICES. In General.--Subchapter IV of chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following new section: ``Sec. 5538. Nonreduction in pay while serving on active duty in a reserve component ``An employee who is also a member of a reserve component and is absent from a position of employment with the Federal Government under a call or order to serve on active duty for a period of more than 30 days shall be entitled to receive, for each pay period described in subsection , an amount equal to the amount by which-- ``the amount of civilian basic pay that would otherwise have been payable to the employee for such pay period if the employee's civilian employment with the Government had not been interrupted by the service on active duty, exceeds (if at all) ``the amount of military compensation that is payable to the employee for the service on active duty and is allocable to such pay period. ``Amounts under this section shall be payable with respect to each pay period (which would otherwise apply if the employee's civilian employment had not been interrupted) that occurs-- ``while the employee serves on active duty for a period of more than 30 days; ``while the employee is hospitalized for, or convalescing from, an illness or injury incurred in, or aggravated during, the performance of such active duty; or ``during the 14-day period beginning at the end of such active duty or the end of the period referred to in subparagraph . ``Paragraph shall not apply with respect to a pay period for which the employee receives civilian basic pay (including by taking any annual, military, or other paid leave) to which the employee is entitled by virtue of the employee's civilian employment with the Government. ``Any amount payable under this section to an employee shall be paid-- ``by the employing agency of the employee; ``from the appropriation or fund that would be used to pay the employee if the employee were in a pay status; and ``to the extent practicable, at the same time and in the same manner as would civilian basic pay if the employee's civilian employment had not been interrupted. ``In consultation with Secretary of Defense, the Office of Personnel Management shall prescribe such regulations as may be necessary to carry out this section. ``In consultation with the Office, the head of each agency referred to in section 2302shall prescribe procedures to ensure that the rights under this section apply to the employees of such agency. ``The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration shall, in consultation with the Office, prescribe procedures to ensure that the rights under this section apply to the employees of that agency. ``For the purpose of this section-- ``the terms `active duty for a period of more than 30 days', `member', and `reserve component' have the meanings given such terms in section 101 of title 37; ``the term `civilian basic pay' includes any amount payable under section 5304; ``the term `employing agency', as used with respect to an employee entitled to any payments under this section, means the agency or other entity of the Government (including an agency referred to in section 2302) with respect to which the employee has reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38; and ``the term `military compensation' has the meaning given the term `pay' in section 101of title 37.''. Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections at the beginning of chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 5537 the following new item: ``5538. Nonreduction in pay while serving on active duty in a reserve component.''. Application of Amendment.--Section 5538 of title 5, United States Code, as added by subsection , shall apply with respect to pay periods (as described in subsection of such section) beginning on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. EMPLOYEES WHO SERVE ON ACTIVE DUTY IN A RESERVE COMPONENT OF THE UNIFORMED SERVICES. In General.--Chapter 17 of title 37, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following new section: ``Sec. 911. Assistance for State and local governments that continue to pay employees who serve on active duty ``Continuation of Civilian Basic Pay.--It is the purpose of this section to encourage States and local governments to continue to pay a portion of the civilian compensation of those employees who are also members of a reserve component and are absent from a position of employment with the State or local government under a call or order to serve on active duty for a period of more than 30 days so that the employees receive compensation in an amount that, when taken together with their military pay, is at least equal to their civilian compensation. ``Reimbursement Offered.--At the request of a State or local government that continues to pay all or a portion of the civilian compensation of an employee described in subsection , the Secretary concerned shall reimburse the State or local government for 50 percent of the civilian compensation paid by the State or local government for each pay period described in subsection , but not to exceed 50 percent of the difference (if any) between-- ``the amount of civilian compensation that would otherwise have been payable to the employee for such pay period if the employee's civilian employment with the State or local government had not been interrupted by the service on active duty; and ``the amount of military pay that is payable to the employee for the service on active duty and is allocable to such pay period. ``If the pay periods described in subsection extend more than nine consecutive months after the first day of the first month during which the employee began to serve on active duty for a period of more than 30 days, the reimbursement rate shall become 100 percent for the subsequent payments. However, as is the case under paragraph , reimbursement shall be provided only for the difference (if any) between-- ``the amount of civilian compensation that would otherwise have been payable to the employee for such pay period if the employee's civilian employment with the State or local government had not been interrupted by the service on active duty; and ``the amount of military pay that is payable to the employee for the service on active duty and is allocable to such pay period. ``Pay Periods.--Reimbursement shall be provided under this section with respect to each pay period (which would otherwise apply if the employee's civilian employment had not been interrupted) that occurs-- ``while the employee serves on active duty for a period of more than 30 days; ``while the employee is hospitalized for, or convalescing from, an illness or injury incurred in, or aggravated during, the performance of such active duty; or ``during the 14-day period beginning at the end of such active duty or the end of the period referred to in subparagraph . ``Effect of Failure To Return to Employment.--If an employee described in subsection , with respect to whom reimbursement is provided to a State or local government under this section, fails to report or apply for employment or reemployment with the State or local government by the end of the period referred to in subsection , the employee shall refund to the Secretary concerned the total amount of the reimbursement provided with respect to the employee. ``Subject to paragraph , an obligation to refund moneys to the United States imposed under paragraph is for all purposes a debt owed to the United States. ``The Secretary concerned may waive, in whole or in part, a refund required under paragraph if the Secretary concerned determines that recovery would be against equity and good conscience or would be contrary to the best interests of the United States. ``A discharge in bankruptcy under title 11 that is entered less than five years after the end of the period referred to in subsection does not discharge the employee from a debt arising under paragraph . This paragraph applies to any case commenced under title 11 after the date of the enactment of this section. ``Regulations.--The Secretaries concerned shall prescribe regulations to carry out this section. ``Definitions.--In this section: ``The term `civilian compensation' means the wages or salary that an employee of a State or local government normally receives from the employee's employment by the State or local government. ``The term `local government' means an agency or political subdivision of a State. ``The term `military pay' has the meaning given the term `pay' in section 101of this title. ``The term `State' means each of the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands, and other territories or possessions of the United States.''. Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections at the beginning of chapter 17 of title 37, is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 909 the following new item: ``911. Assistance for State and local governments that continue to pay employees who serve on active duty.''. Application of Amendment.--Section 911 of title 37, United States Code, as added by subsection , shall apply with respect to pay periods (as described in subsection of such section) beginning on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. BUSINESS CREDIT. Addition of Credit.--Subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to business- related credits) is amended by adding at the end the following new section: `` ``General Rule.--For purposes of section 38, in the case of an employer, the active-duty reserve component employee credit determined under this section for the taxable year is an amount equal to 50 percent of the compensation paid by the employer to an employee who is also a member of a reserve component during the taxable year when the employee was absent from employment for a reason described in subsection . ``Limitation.--The amount allowed as a credit under subsection shall not exceed 50 percent of the difference (if any) between-- ``the amount of compensation that would otherwise have been payable to the employee during such absence if the employee's employment with the employer had not been interrupted by the employee's absence; and ``the amount of military pay that is payable to the employee during the absence. ``Covered Pay Periods.--Subsection shall apply with respect to an employee who is also a member of a reserve component-- ``while the employee serves on active duty for a period of more than 30 days; ``while the employee is hospitalized for, or convalescing from, an illness or injury incurred in, or aggravated during, the performance of such active duty; or ``during the 14-day period beginning at the end of such active duty or the end of the period referred to in paragraph . ``Days Not Taken Into Account.--No credit shall be allowed under subsection with respect to an employee on any day on which the employee was not scheduled to work (for a reason other than such service on active duty) and ordinarily would not have worked. ``Definitions.--For purposes of this section-- ``The terms `active duty for a period of more than 30 days', `member', and `reserve component' have the meanings given such terms in section 101 of title 37, United States Code. ``The term `compensation' means any remuneration for employment, whether in cash or in kind, which is paid or incurred by a taxpayer and which is deductible from the taxpayer's gross income under section 162.''. Credit To Be Part of General Business Credit.--Subsection of section 38 of such Code (relating to general business credit) is amended by striking ``plus'' at the end of paragraph , by striking the period at the end of paragraph and inserting ``, plus'', and by adding at the end the following new paragraph: ``the active-duty reserve component employee credit determined under section 45N.''. Conforming Amendment.--The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of such Code is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 45M the following new item: ``Sec. 45N. Active-duty reserve component employee credit.''. Effective Date.--The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007."</BILL><SUMMARY>Strengthening the Transition and Reintegration of National Guard and Reserve Components Act or the Strongr Act - Directs the Secretary of Defense to administer the Act through FY2018, with provisions regarding transitional health care coverage for members of the selected reserve components for mental health care.Amends the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Act to: (1) increase in the amount of basic educational assistance for members of the selected reserve and members of reserve components supporting contingency operations; (2) reduce the maximum allowable amount of assistance for a member of a reserve component; and (3) allow for an additional 180 days, for mental health care only, to a Member of a Reserve Component (RUSC) to provide such assistance.Provides for: (1) an educational assistance allowance for a month after the date of enactment of this Act; (2) reserve components supporting contingency operations; and (3) an additional reserve component for such operations.Amends the Federal Employment Standards Act to: (1) reduce federal employee's pay while serving on active duty in a reserve component of the Federal Government; and (2) make such pay available to an employee who is also a member of such component and is absent from a call or order to serve for a period of more than one year.30 Days of Active Duty Compensation - Amends the Military Retirement Act of 2003 to require the Department of Defense to provide 30-day civilian basic pay terms, equal to the amount of military compensation that would otherwise have been payable to the employee for such a period if the employee's civilian employment had not been interrupted.Directs the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration to prescribe procedures to ensure that the rights under this Act apply to the employees of such agencies.Authorizes the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to administer civilian basic pay and military compensation programs.Requires the Secretary of State to provide State and local governments with paid civilian compensation for employees who serve on active duty in a reserve component of the uniformed services.Prohibits reimbursement for the difference between the civilian compensation that would otherwise have been payable to the employee for such pay period if the employee's civilian employment with the State or local government had not been interrupted by the service on active duty.Prohibits an employee from filing for unemployment compensation or re-employment if: (1) while the employee is hospitalized for, or convalescing from, an illness or injury incurred in, or aggravated during, the performance of such duty; or (2) during the 14-day active duty or the end of such period.Directs the Secretaries concerned to prescribe regulations to carry out this Act.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend the active-duty reserve component employee credit to pay periods beginning on or after the date of the enactment of this Act; and (2) require an employer to provide such credit to employees who serve on active duty with respect to compensation paid to an employee who is also a member of a reserve component.Provides for: (1) no credit for the amount of compensation that would otherwise have been payable to an employee during such absence if the employee's employment with the employer had not been interrupted by the employee; and (2) a 14-day period beginning at the end of such active duty or the end before such such period.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require such credit to be part of general business credit.</SUMMARY><BILL_FROM>../../preprocess/data/clean_billsum_test.csv</BILL_FROM><SUMMARY_FROM>../../output/deliverable_4/wugNATSS-led/eval_on_unsimp.csv</SUMMARY_FROM><ALIGNSCORE>0.18086884915828705</ALIGNSCORE>
<ROW>98</ROW><BILL>"This Act may be cited as the ``Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005''. (CASH AND COUNSELING). Exemption From Certain Requirements.--Section 1915 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1396n) is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection: ``A State may provide, as `medical assistance', payment for part or all of the cost of self-directed personal assistance services (other than room and board) under the plan which are provided pursuant to a written plan of care to individuals with respect to whom there has been a determination that, but for the provision of such services, the individuals would require and receive personal care services under the plan, or home and community-based services provided pursuant to a waiver under sub-section .
